title: What are the best ways to make money as a teenager? - Quora

response.answer_text: I. Work for myself Think of this as a show or a business. You can work on your own, or you can start a small company by partnering with friends. Yes, teamwork means the profits will have to be split, but also means a lot of work can be done quickly and more importantly, safety, which means you can be more flexible. When working with friends, divide work fairly and fairly (rotate work if possible to make people happy), gather in groups after class or on weekends around the neighborhood. , then get hired for a variety of jobs that can be completed quickly at a fixed price. A lot of people will turn their backs on a teenager when they see him knocking on their door for fear that he looks suspicious. But if they see you working in a group, they'll trust you to get in and out of their house quickly without disturbing your neighbors. If you are making money for a specific purpose (for example, buying an instrument, going on a field trip), tell everyone that; they will often buy from someone with a specific purpose of making money and maybe even pay you a little extra. 2. Consider doing common tasks. Babysitting, taking a dog for a walk, washing a car, or even videotaping and posting online with a genuine partnership, then you can make a lot of money from this job. Or you can mow the lawn for neighbors' houses. You can make a lot of money, but it takes hard work and a lot of weekend time. If you are distracted or depressed, remind yourself that hard work will produce real results. Set up groups for new jobs such as landscape decoration: a lawn mower, a water gutter cleaner, a hedge trimmer, and a pile of bricks and tiles. Ask your parents or parents of friends to lend 4. Doing chores in the house Talk to your parents about assigning chores to you. Try to choose things that parents may have to hire workers to do, like cleaning the toilet and only taking parents for half the price. Ask your parents if you can move every week. Wash your own clothes and wash dishes. Make sure you do a good job doing chores in the home or your parents will think you are not doing well for the money your parents pay you. If you don't have a lot of work to do, you can find other ways to make money (for example, "If your child is really trying to save water and electricity, parents can pay for the amount of money their family saves compared to chemicals). last month? "). Sometimes parents will be willing to help you if they know your plan, so share details with your parents. 5. Running errands for the elderly. Go for groceries, lift heavy things, repair computers or do whatever they are having trouble with. Try to make a good relationship with those people; Remember that they may feel very lonely and may enjoy spending time with young people as friends (Make them feel younger). The happier they are with you, the more they will pay you for the services you provide. 6. Bring trash to the curb. The day before the garbage truck arrives, go to all the families in the neighborhood you live in and ask to be paid VND 10,000 for you to take all the garbage to the curb to help them. (Don't ask for more; this is a simple job, so you have to maintain a reasonable price proportional to idle to get people more excited.) If you can collect garbage for twenty families, you have earned up to 200,000 VND with almost nothing to do. You may be even more fortunate if you work in the community of the elderly or the area you know may have many elderly people living. Do not do this in drainage areas or in the homes of any strangers for any reason. It is better to have an ally working in some situations 7. Start with the car wash job. Car wash and car care is a great money-making idea. With just a few people all the work can be done easily: one person wash and scrub the car, one takes care of the windows, the other two are in charge of the interior. Remember to vacuum thoroughly inside the car, scrub the wheel with a wax wheel, scrub the inside with a plastic brush (if the surface is plastic), and do it very carefully. Remember, if people don't like the results of your work, they can rely on professionals and can get it done for less. Always remember who you are competing with. 8. Disposal of old furniture. If you have a yard, consider selling second hand goods. You will be surprised to see how quickly they sell. Clean out your closet, attic, basement, and collect whatever else in your home is no longer needed and post ads for sale in the yard. Everything can give you some money. "Promotion" added by inviting shoppers for light, inexpensive drinks and beverages. It could be lemonade or popcorn if the weather is nice; or hot cup of tea if it's cold. You can sell for "super" cheap prices (because they sell second hand goods), almost for free, or for free, but accept donations (some people may be more generous than you think). If you have time, you can also make your own for sale. Just make sure you're still profitable! You have to consider the cost of raw materials. If you're serious about selling something, learn more about bargaining. 9. Advertise its services. Order a low-cost newspaper or online advertising such as babysitting, babysitting, pet care, etc. You can also hand out leaflets and business cards to people who need help advertising. Craigslist is a great website for you to provide your services, but consider having a parent or guardian for you when you plan to do business; Business is not the ideal job, but there are still many people out there trying to take advantage of you, and you need to prepare yourself well. You don't need to worry, but there are still many things to be aware of. I use update part II. We look forward to the support of the people You can contribute comments here

Disclaimer-Not sure what your gender is because you didn't specifically mention it so I'm just going to write this answer from a boys point of view. There are five main ways to earn money as a teen that I know of Mow lawns. I know, I know, typical answer, one you've probably gotten from countless others already, but it truly is a great first job. It requires little experience or skill, you pretty much have an infinite supply of lawns to mow (I garuntee if you ask around enough and offer a reasonable (or less than reasonable, you're not a professional after all) price, you’ll find plenty of jobs), and you don't need too many expensive tools (either you or this person likely already has a lawn mower). It does have a few cons though, which I will put in bullet form after each example.Physical laborNot always the best payCan get boring and requires a vehicle (unless you’re mowing your neighbors lawns)Garage sale. This is mainly if you need some quick cash for something and not a permanent job. Surely you have some old toys or clothes that you don't use any more laying around your room. My friend in middle school sold off all his Pokémon card collection along with his baby clothes once and pulled in nearly $200. Cons:Could be tough to convince your parents to let you do thisYou need semi-valuabmale stuff to sell, people won't just buy junkNeed to live in a house; appartment won't doOne-offAsk your parents to set up an allowance for you. This one is probably the simplest. Just ask your parents if they’d be willing to give you a weekly or monthly allowance. Tell them that it would teach you fiscal responsibility and offer to do more chores around the house to compensate. If they still won't budge, ask them to start off with something small, maybe $1–3 a week, and just save it all until you have enough for whatever you want (dont forget to put some in the bank, too). Just remember, your parents might not be able to afford this, so don't push it too hard, and be understanding if they say no. Cons:Small amount of money over long period of timeMight take some convincing to get your parents to pay you anythingNot affordable for some familiesSell stuff at school. This is probably the most lucrative of all the methods listed here. You can sell pretty much anything at school, be it food, supplies, shoes, or even homework answers (not recommended but hey, don't shoot the messenger). Simply buy stuff at a super cheap conscience store, or other people, as is the case with shoes, and then resell it for a higher price. Easy profit, especially selling to kids with parents who wouldn't let them buy that kind of stuff normally. Cons:99.99% chance it's not allowed at your school (but hey, that doesn't mean it's impossible to get away with it. Just be smart about it)You’ll need an older sibling, really chill parent, or other trusted older friend to buy the stuff in the first place, then give it to you to sell at school (remember to kick them a few dollars if you have one of the 3)Selling shoes and answers are both pretty riskyGet a traditional job. This is going to be the most difficult, if not downright impossible, depdending on where you live, thing to do. First, you’ll need a work permit from your school’s principal (depending on your age, it varies by state). You’ll need to set up an appointment with him/her and tell them where you plan on working, how long you plan on working a week, and how it will effect your grades (you’ll need to maintain decent to good grades (B- to A+ ish) if you even want your principle to consider it. On top of that, you'll need to find a teen friendly job, like busing tables, limited cooking, limited cleaning, theme park ride attendant, or parking attendant. Cons:Lots of convincing both your parents and schools admins that you are mature and responsible enough to get a jobFinding a place that will hire a teen. (Just ask around at your favorite restaurants if they are hiring and during your interview try to act as mature and as grown up as you can.)Realizimg that this is a real-life commitment, and that you won't have as much time to hang out with your friends or do other social/fun like that if you take this job.Keeping your grades upThat's really all that I could think of. If you’re a girl, I'm so sorry! I couldn't think of anything other than baby-sitting (in addition to the boys list) that you could do, and I don't know enough about babysitting to say anythign about it with any level of authority. Hope this helped! Edit 1: spelling and grammar

There are many ways for a teenager to make some money. This money can be the equivalent of ‘pocket money’, to serious money, to retirement money. Sometimes, it’s not even about the money. When you start your own enterprise at a young age, like I did (I will tell you more about my experience below) you gain priceless experience and knowledge to start your next business. Then another after that. See where I’m going? This is source to true riches. In today’s world, opportunity presents itself more and more to those who look for it. This is partially because of the technological revolution that's come before us. Allowing us to find help, communicate, advertise and so much more. The younger you are to take advantage of that, the better chance you will have to succeeding in entrepreneurship.   (Source: Millionaires Under 20 | New Rich - Alux.com) This is Tyler Dikman. He became a millionaire before he hit the golden age of 20. He started his first business at the age of 13, CoolTronics. He started his venture with the purpose of teaching people how to clean up their computer viruses and he went from there. Through advertising and subscription fees, he’s current net-worth is now $3.2 million.   (Source: Millionaires Under 20 | New Rich - Alux.com) Here is Sean Belnick. Many of you may already know this man as the founder of Bizchair, an online retailer which sells office furniture. Before I go on, I want you to think about the last time you had $500, and what you did with that money. Did you spend it all alcohol for the streak of summer parties ahead? Did you buy the new PlayStation? Not this kid. With $500 he started his enterprise. According to Young Entrepreneurs, he locked himself in his room for three days at the age of 14 and built his website. Skip forward a few years (eight years to be precise), and this kid is now worth the best part of $59 million.  What this goes to prove is that none of these young entrepreneurs, and many more like them around the world, where handed the opportunity to start their own business. Instead, through perseverance and entrepreneurial passion, they found it themselves.  When I was kid, at around the age of 11, just settling in at my new school in a sleepy town called Henley on Thames, I found my opportunity. In my school, there was a rule disallowing the purchase of sweets and chocolates in the canteen, and so it wasn't stocked. I decided to stock it. I started buying sweets at chocolate at discount from Costco and started selling them at double the cost. For example, I would buy a pack of four Mars bars for £1 and sell each one for 50 pence. I made a 100% return on my investment. But, I had a problem. I couldn’t feed 1,000 chocolate hungry mouths on my own during the hour I had for lunch, and so I started to employ my first ever employees. Coming to the end of the year, I was pocketing around £40 a day after expenses in just the one hour I had for lunch. That’s £200 a week and £800 a month. I was making more money than some of the staff working at my school. This brings me to my first point I mentioned earlier, because although I was making a fair amount of money for an 11 year old at the time, it wasn't enough to change my life. Instead, I gained priceless knowledge and experience to help me with my future ventures. For example, I learnt how to manage my employees, I learnt to appreciate basic use of accounting. In effect, I learnt business. This is something I carry with me today, and will build on in the future. Have a look on my Quora Profile for a summary of my business life starting at the age 7: Mo Amini  (Source: Emirates247) My point in writing this answer goes out to all the young and aspiring entrepreneurs of our future. To find a way to make money, you have to ‘look’. That’s the key. In every nook and cranny there is a potential for a business, and if you look harder, life changing potentials will stare back at you and make you think to yourself “why hasn't anyone done this before”. Truth is, others probably have, but they’re not the entrepreneur, if you want to, you can be the one to exploit that. You can choose to be the entrepreneur.  Have you heard about the law of averages? It’s a principle that states: an event is more likely to occur if there is enough frequency of trials made for it. My advice for you is to apply the law of averages. Start as many businesses as you can when you’re young, because even if you fail, the knowledge and skills you acquire in the process are priceless for you, and your future. This will lead you to your riches. The famous Footballer Lionel Messi, in a way, applied the law of averages because he practiced more and more until he made it. He said (Lionel Messi - Twitter): “It took me 17 years and 114 days to become an overnight success.” Let that sink in for a little bit. Give it a go. Good luck.

I had a variety of jobs while I was in High School. I started out at 15 years old working as a Cashier at a McDonald's that was within walking distance of my Parents house. I made $6.75 as a starting minimum wage and absolutely hated the job. I worked mostly weekends but I found the smell of french fries following me well into the school week. I knew it was only temporary and that once I turned 16 many more options would open up for me to move onto something new. After 6 months working as a Cashier I quit my job at McDonald's. I was done making french fries, taking orders, and cleaning bathrooms. I was ready to level up. After turning 16, I dressed up in a nice business outfit and hit the mall with an updated resume in my hand. I was determined to find a job and wouldn’t come home until an interview had been scheduled. I submitted an application and spoke to the Hiring Managers of just about every single retail store in the whole mall. After lining up a few interviews I was hired as a Sales Associate at Finish Line making $7.50 per hour. I had always had an interest in sales and wanted to develop my skills so I figured what better way then sell something I already love. I became an up-selling master ($1 added to each paycheck for selling cleaner or waterproof), implemented a variety of mind-hacks to use on my end customers and began to make an extra dollar here and there as the sales incentives began to kicked in. I was loving my new job and finally started to feel like I was doing things right. Only problem was the hours were limited and I still had free time to devote to working and making more money. I decided to take a second job as a Bus Boy cleaning and clearing tables at the Texas Roadhouse. I really liked this job from the start mainly due to the fact I was surrounded by a continuous stream of the hottest girls in my area. The wait staff were typically chicks and the majority were all a few years older than me. Great second job and I loved the cash tips. Problem is soon I started to realize I wasn’t really making that much money and the job was keeping me at the restaurant late at night so by the time I’d get off work it would be too late to do anything with my friends. So I began looking for a new source of income. What did I find? The best job I EVER had while I was in High School was delivering PIZZA at a local town sub shop right next to the original McDonald's I had worked in back when I was 15. It was the best job for a variety of reasons. I got paid straight cash a base salary of $8 per hour plus tips. Little did I know I had just landed the dream job for any high school kid. I live in a Suburb where most houses would give anywhere from a $3–7 tip so I was now going home with what would come out to about $16–18 per hour after each shift. To be honest out of all of my friends or acquaintances I was making more money simply driving pizzas around literally doing no work besides driving because my boss was a control freak and wouldn’t even allow me to help with anything in the restaurant. He would give me the remote to the TV when there were no deliveries and even let me nap when I was hungover from partying with friends all night. If I have any advice to give. Find the opportunity that either pays you a bunch without doing any real “work” or one that pays you little but teaches you a lot so you can add value down the road and make 10x the money when the timing is right! And if you find one that pays you a lot and teaches you a lot..Now you are really on to something big!

Despite the difficult economy, there are many ways for a teenager to make money. All you need is a good idea and some free time. Read these money-making ideas for inspiration. 1. Work for yourself. Treat it like a program or business. You can work by yourself, or you can start a mini-company by joining together with your friends. Yes, group work means splitting up the funds, but it also means you can get a lot of jobs done quickly and, more importantly, safely, which means you will also be able to go more places. When working with your friends, divide the tasks fairly and equally (rotating if it keeps everyone happy), take your group around the neighborhood after school or on weekends, and offer to get various tasks done quickly for a set price. A lot of people will turn away a lone teenager knocking at their door for fear that it will look suspicious. If they see that you’re working as a team, however, they’ll know you can get in and out quickly without concerning the neighbors. If you are raising money toward a specific goal (ex. buying an instrument, being able to go on a school trip), let people know; they’ll be much more likely to buy stuff from someone with a purpose and may even give you extra. 2. Consider the basics. Babysit, walk dogs, wash cars, or even record videos and put them online, with the right partnership company, there is a lot of money in it. Or mow lawns for your neighbors. You can make a lot of money, but it's hard work and could take up much of the weekend. If you get distracted or depressed, remind yourself that your hard work will lead to very real results. Team up to do odd jobs like landscaping: One person mows, one cleans the gutters, one clips the hedges, one rakes up all the debris. Ask your parents and your friends' parents for all the necessary tools, or rent them from a supply store. 3. Shovel snow. Go to every house in a good sized neighborhood charging 10-20 dollars per driveway, or 30 dollars a week for shoveling the snow. (Charge extra when shoveling snow that has been driven on, which is packed down and very hard to remove.) Do this every time it snows. Someone may pay you in advance for a month if they know you, or if they like your work! 4. Do work around the house. Negotiate fees with your parents for extra chores around the house. Try to pick things they might hire a professional to do, like cleaning the toilets, and charge them half price. Ask your parents if you can clean the house each week. Do your laundry and the dishes. Be sure to do the chores properly or your parents might not think it's worth their money. If there isn’t much work to be done, you might even be able to work out some other kind of arrangement (ex. "If I work really hard to save water and electricity, will you pay me the amount of money we saved on the bill since last month?"). Parents are sometimes more willing to help out if they know what your plan is, so share all the details with them. 5. Run errands for an elderly person. Get groceries, do heavy lifting, troubleshoot the computer, or do any other tasks they might have trouble with. Try to have a good relationship with the person; remember that they might be lonely and probably enjoy spending time around younger people such as friends. (It makes them feel younger.) The better they feel around you, the more they'll be likely to give you for your services. 6. Take trash to the curb. On the day before trash pickup, hit up all the houses on your street and ask for a dollar from each house to take all the bins out to the curb. (Don’t ask for any more than this; it’s a super simple job, so you have to maintain a reasonable cost-to-laziness ratio to get anyone interested.) If it works on even twenty houses, that’s twenty bucks for almost no work. You might have even better luck in a retirement community or an area where you know a lot of elderly people happen to live. Don’t do this in sketchy areas or go into anyone’s house for any reason. You might be better off working with a partner in some situations. 7. Start a car wash. Car washing and detailing is another great money-making idea. This is done most easily with several people: one person rinses and scrubs, one does windows, two detail the inside. Remember to thoroughly vacuum the inside, hit the wheels with wheel wax, rub the inside with vinyl scrub (if the surface is vinyl), and do a thorough job. Remember, if people don't like your work, they can probably go to a professional and get the job done cheaper. Keep in mind who you're competing against. 8. Sell items at a yard sale. Even if you don’t think you have anything lying around that anyone will want, you’d be surprised by how quickly a lot of little sales can add up. Empty out your closet, attic, or basement and gather together everything you don’t want. Put all the small-ticket items into a group to be sold at a yard sale, which you can advertise with street signs and Craigslist. (Often, clothes in nice condition will sell at a yard sale. Worthless clothes, especially simple tees, can be cleaned and sold in bundles as shop rags.) Make a little extra at a yard sale by offering simple, cheap beverages or snacks. If it’s nice weather, offer lemonade, individual baggies of popcorn (stove-popped, not microwave-popped, which is way more expensive), or other sunny day refreshments; if it’s cold or blustery, offer hot tea or cider. You can either sell these at a very low rate (it’s a yard sale, after all), give them away (making people more likely to buy out of niceness and good will), or offer them for free but accept donations (some people will blow you out of the water with their generosity). If you have the time, you can also make or build things to sell. Just make sure that there’s room for profit! You have to keep in mind things like materials cost. If you're serious about selling things, learn how to haggle. 9. Advertise your services. Place a cheap ad in the newspaper or online for something like babysitting, house-sitting, pet-sitting, etc. You can also pass out flyers and business cards for people who need help advertising. Craigslist is a great place to offer your services, but plan on having a parent or guardian accompany you when you scope for work; it's probably not ideal, but there are people out there who could try to take advantage of you, and you want to be prepared. It's nothing to worry about, but it's something to be aware of.

There are a slew of things you can do. As stated in previous answers walking dogs (I did this, it is intimidating going up to neighbors and asking, but,  you would be amazed at how many are more than willing since they are gone during most the day.) Selling water bottles at events.  This is also great.  Good margins, and people are thirsty. Another thing that might be of more interest to you is trying to do "grown up things" I say that in quotes since I feel we are all still kids as adults. Such as, trying to build a website for local small businesses.  Or running their social media campaign. Starting a cleaning business. Putting up a small gumball machine in a card shop, or any small business that has high foot traffic. (Here you offer the owner a cut of your profits for renting his floor space, buy gumballs online or at costco etc). Offering tutoring lessons in classes you excel in.  Or tutoring to younger students. Playing video games that you are great at and live streaming on twitch.tv. Making youtube or vine videos daily (you will fail A LOT before you make any money but when you do will make money for years) Making art, or neat things such as a cool watch, cool tshirt, cool sneakers etc, and selling it on etsy. Finding items on amazon or walmart that are cheaper than on ebay and selling them on ebay by gifting it to them. (Yes this exists think about how you out of habbit only go to certain websites even though alternatives exist) Going on alibaba and finding a product that you can buy bulk and sell on amazon, ebay, or etsy for more. Delivering news papers via bike. Seatching craigslist for odd jobbs (example I need this trash taken to dumpster, or my lawn mowed). Going on task rabbit and finding things people need done. Trading your way up, or bartering with items.  Back to craigs list here and find a item in the "free" section and then finding if you can sell it, fix it, and resell it. You should note that as a teenager you have a few key advantages over most adults.  Time, you are trained to learn right now due to the number of years you have been going to school.  So you can throw a dart to a dartboard of ideas and learn how via trial and error and research (I suggest trial and error first then research as I feel your learning curve is quicker once you have already failed but learned). Freeedom, the only laws you live by are those set by your parents, and like any good teenager im sure you break those often ;) Hope this helps.

All I see is "value, value, value". It's the same people copy and pasting there long, pointless essay's all over Quora. No one cares about your vague content. Regardless of how many upvotes you get, it's not the answer people are looking for.  Second, why do people ask these instead of searching??? There are thousands of unique answers!   Okay, now that I got that out of the way, let's take a look.  It all boils down to time and motivation. At 15, you have more time than you'll ever have.  Ask yourself, do you need someone to push you to do things OR do you handle everything better on your own?  I ask this because you need to decide if you want to take on the traditional teenager jobs or start from scratch and invent your own way of making money. If you need someone to tell you what to do, find a local job for $10 an hour.  But, your on Quora. I'm going to assume your motivated and know a nice deal about the Internet. Use this "Internet". Here are some other options.   Instead of the $10 an hour, let's make that $50..every hour...24 hours, 7 days a week. How? Instead of all the other answers, I'm going to give you options. Here's the deal. Choose one, and paste it into Quora. But choose wisely; after you do, you must stick with it. No coming back (If you find your niche and ever comeback, you'll know why I said this). The best way these days is to learn a skill (assuming you don't already have one) and then teach it. It could be doing make-up or it could be astrophysics.   The Options:  -YouTube! Make videos and grow a channel! This one doesn't need an explanation these days. -Start up a blog on ANYTHING! Monetize music on SoundCloud (random but maybe you love music)Amazon Affilite - If someone clicks your link to an Amazon item, you get  a percent. Teach a course on a subscription education service like Lynda (Tough but some of these guys make 100K...a month).Drop Shipping: To in depth to be summed up into one sentenceMoney on Twitter (if you get like 1.0m followers) by giving smaller accounts shout outs. Monetize a Facebook page that posts funny contentRedesign local web sites. Take pictures and sell them on Fotolia/istockphotos!Think of an app idea and use Quora to find someone who can make it happen.Famous on social media? Use link shortener to get paid when people click your link.Order things from china and sell on EbayKnow how to  do everything, become a virtual assistant for some CEO...Domain Flipping! If your rich already and doing this for kicks, buy a bunch of .com's and sell them like, 40 years for now for...A LOT. You can turn any of these into a small business and then automate it. If you start thinking at 15, start it at 16, and generated income by 17. Imagine where you'll be by 18. The idea isn't to get rich. It's to start now so later on...you set! But, the deadly part is the money. If you focus on it, you motivation will dwindle and die. Instead, focus on the bigger picture.  "The best way to make money is to not think about making money" - Not Enough People Cheers!

The easiest and most profitable thing to do would be to get a job in retail or fast food. Other than that, babysitting and tutoring. Mowing lawns. Cleaning pools. That kind of stuff. But you probably know all of that that. Perhaps you want something more exciting. When I was growing up quite a few of us poor benighted inner city kids had some sort of money-making idea or practice. Whether or not they were super profitable, they were (usually) fun and often a learning experience. I will list them for you here, and you may take from it what you will. Candy/Snack Selling One kid in my high school did this and made a killing. He got everything in bulk and sold candy and sodas for $1 each. The teachers tended to look the other way (as far as I recall) so long as he didn’t disrupt classes. I have heard that some schools frown on this though, and schools with vending machines in particular crack down hard on this -so much for capitalism, am I right? Also, the barrier to entry is very low, so expect competition. Gambling There will almost always be opportunities to bet money on something. In my day Yu-Gi-Oh was the big game (yes, really), and there were always opportunities to gamble for money or cards (which could later be sold for money). New York City -my home- had an unusually vast and extremely sketchy Yu-Gi-Oh community at the time, which again meant lots of opportunity to gamble. But you can bet on literally anything if you want. Needless to say, while you can make money, you could just as easily lose money gambling. And then there’s the matter of collecting your winnings, which isn’t always easy. If you beat someone in a bet, and he refuses to pay up, well, what are you gonna do about it? If you don’t have an answer, you shouldn’t be gambling. Or at least, not with people you don’t trust. And then of course, sometimes the game is just straight-up rigged against you. I once had two friends invite me into a rigged game: the idea was that they would play Yu-Gi-Oh during the lunch period and stir up interest to get people to bet on the game. The idea was to get a lot of people to bet on “Friend A” to win; Friend A would then throw the game to Friend B, who would take the pot. They would then divide the earnings between themselves later. My job was to help stoke interest in the game. I turned them down, but let them know I wouldn’t get involved either way -meaning I wouldn’t tell anyone. So the next day they’re doing their thing and they get a nice pool of money going from a few surrounding suckers. So far so good for their side hustle. Unfortunately they left said pool of money in the open, in the middle of the lunch table. A scary upper-classman walked by, saw what was going on, reached down and stole the money, and walked away. Whoops. Loan Sharking This was something I dabbled in. I was a finance nerd growing up, and was obsessed with the idea of having my money make money. I only had a few dollars to my name so opportunity was limited. That was until a friend asked to borrow like, $2.50 from me. At that moment, inspiration came. I loaned him the money, but at $0.25 interest a day until it was paid back (pulled the number out of thin air). He was trustworthy so I knew he’d pay and pay quickly. He agreed to the terms and said he’d probably pay me back later that day -before my interest kicked in. This worried me. I was happy to be paid back, but I wanted to make money. So I had another stroke of genius -what if I sold his debt to someone else? The debtor was trustworthy, and I reckoned I could convince someone to buy the debt for $3.00 once I explained that the interest rate on the debt would push the amount owned passed that in just a few days. Yes, it was genius. I was a genius. I would turn $2.50 into $3.00 in just a few hours.  So I spent a few periods trying to hawk this $2.50 (w/ $0.25 interest) debt around to people. No one knew what the fuck I was talking about. “You, Ke’Aun, want me to… buy a debt? What?” And it’s not like I was a good salesman -I didn’t understand how to sell a product beyond just reiterating the same words over and over. Later that day my friend gave me back my $2.50. No profit for me. =’( Another time I loaned out $15 to a less trustworthy person at a gigantic $5 a day interest rate. Boy was I excited for this payday; I was imaging all night that night what I would do with the money. Of course he never paid me back. And I had no method of making him pay me back -what was I going to do, break his legs? I mean, had I been more… gangsta, let’s say, I guess I could’ve done something, but I wasn’t and still aren’t. Like gambling, don’t bet what you can’t collect on.  You will note that all of these opportunities are either 1) not very profitable, 2) risky, or 3) both. If you really want (safe) money as a teen, get a job. Your employer can later be used as a reference on your resume or college applications, which alone is probably going to be worth more than the pennies you earn doing something more “cool.” The only other thing I can think of is to create something to sell, like a work of art, a book, an invention, etc. That can work, if you have the skill and tenacity for it.

There are tons of ideas out there to start a business. What you really need is a good idea and a great execution to make it a successful business. Since execution is more important that the actual business idea, it is important for you to understand the process to start a business, sustain and thrive. The Process: Step 1: Come up with the idea For ideas, you just need to keep your windows open (ears and eyes). Most of the time, a new business idea is just around the corner. Identify the problems you face (or others face) in general and then figure out ways to solve them in a better way. On the other hand, if there’s something that you love to do and would like to focus all your energy on it, convert it into a process and start a business. One of the way is to look at the new business trends and upcoming technologies and how you can use them to come up with something that would touch the lives of others. Step 2: Validate your idea Once you come up with the idea, you will need to validate it in the market. Talk to people who matter to you and get their feedback. Run an ad on Google/ Facebook and build your first email list of people who would like to purchase your product/service upon launch. Step 3: Build your MVP One of the mistake that many entrepreneurs make is to spend the whole time and effort to build a fully blown product. Start small and make iterations. MVP is like a working prototype of your whole idea. Create a minimum viable product and validate it in the market. Use a crowdsource funding/ ideas to create your MVP and find your first users. Step 4: Launch Let everyone know that you’ve built something that is useful to them. Spend the time to market you product, since it takes most of the effort. Catch hold of your first users and see if they refer to others and help with word of mouth. The Idea: Per the latest trend, the on-demand economy is booming. It’s exciting that you get what you want, with just a click. This business model has seen an exponential rise in the past year or so, indicating that speed and convenience are highly valued among consumers. Thinking on these lines, come up with an idea to provide a service or deliver a product at the convenience of the consumer. The competition is tough and pretty much crowded by now, but if you can capture the local market and provide value, you can slowly expand to other areas and grow your business.

Forget doing e-commerce! I was a drop-shipper for a year and while I did make money, but the money was indifferent.  In my limited business experiences( software as a service, ebay dropshipping, Gift card reselling, and Airbnb Rental Arbitrage), I’d say the answer is Airbnb Rental Arbitrage. Let’s explore all of them. Software as a service I have worked for 3 different software companies in San Francisco. The startup costs are high as tech workers cost a lot of money. Once you built a successful product, you not only have to think about product maintenance, but marketing, and customer support. These costs are fixed costs. Not only that, you will have to figure out a product that people will want. Is your product going to be B2C or B2B? The next phase is the market research. Well, you get the idea. Lots of work go into research… This article summarizes profit margins for software companies pretty good. Most software companies have margin less than 20%. And most businesses would consider a 20% margin a great business. Ebay Dropshipping I started an Ebay dropshipping store in 2017. I’ve made probably $5000 in sales. Not a lot, but enough for me to understand my thruput. Throughput = (time invested in researching for product ideas/niches + time running the dropshipping store) / the profit (revenue minus item costs) So for example, I’d spend time researching for a niche product to sell on ebay, let’s say, snow gloves, and then I’d create an ad on ebay to dropship the snow gloves that I found from Alibaba. Let’s assume the gloves go for $15 on Alibaba and I would charge 1.4x of the original cost, so 15 * 1.4 = 21 dollars. 21 dollars minus ebay and paypal fees = 19 dollars. So my net profit would be 4 dollars. So, I’d earn 4 dollars for every 21 dollars. That means my profit margin would be roughly 19%. Well, 19% is still not a bad profit margin. Just to give you a reference point, Apple’s products are around 38%. Gift Card Reselling I gave up on the business idea after 2 weeks. Too many scammers tried to hustle me. My time ROI was negative. Airbnb Rental Arbitrage I’ve been doing this for over a year now. My profit margin varies from month to month, but it averages from 42% to 58%. This all depends on occupancy rate and the time of the year. What is Airbnb Arbitrage? In this case, you are renting a property out at a lower price and subleasing it out via Airbnb at a higher price. For example, you lease a 1-bedroom apartment at $1,000 dollars a month and rent out the same 1-bedroom for $2,000 dollars a month on Airbnb. Your net profit is $1k a month. In the month August in 2017, my net income was $12,345. After my business expenses, my profit was 7089. That is 58% profit margin! Best part about this business model is that you lease homes and not own them. Once the business is up and running, I spend only a few hours each week managing the business. Hope this helps! P.S. I teach other entrepreneurs how to build an Airbnb business on PassiveAirbnb.com

Stock market? Make a mobile app? Let's assume this kid is not a genius and give him some reasonable and achievable suggestions. Here are some ideas. 1. Get a retail job.Sales clerk, stockboy, or you can be like me and work at a fast food chain (mine's was KFC).  Pros: get work experience, easy to get the job, feel awesome you're earning moneyCons: crap pay, crap work, and anything you do will likely not be useful on a resume in the future. 2. Provide neighborhood services.Lawn mowing, weed whacking, car washing, car waxing, dog walking, babysitting, dog washing, gutter cleaning, dog poop scooping, recycling, grocery delivery... and on and on. Just ask around your neighborhood and see what types of need there are. This is basic entrepreneurship/business dealing and it's great because all of the above are things that need to be done over and over (recurring revenue, my friend).  Pros: fun to think of ideas, fun to execute, get referrals from within the community, and people will be so glad that you do the shit they don't want to do :)Cons: your ideas might be bad, you might mess up people's stuff, you're inexperienced, and you will have to market yourself  3. Sell things at strategic locations.This is one thing that I saw a lot of in South Korea when I worked there, where there was a lot of public solicitation on the sidewalks and subways (although it's illegal). Is it raining outside? Find a busy place with a lot of foot traffic and sell umbrellas. At a football tailgate? Sell home team jerseys. Fourth of July parade? Sell American flags. Sunny day at the touristy beach? Sell a visor or sunscreen.  Pros: you can make a killing if you sell the right thing in the right locationCons: solicitation laws vary. also, it's up to you to buy the items for cheap beforehand and choose the price to mark it up to **** Read this post by Mark Cuban (owner of the Dallas Mavericks and serial entrepreneur): Making Money as a Student

When I started re-skinning apps, I was 18. Over the past two year, I’ve found that re-skinning apps is one of the best ways to make money online. Last year I was able to make over $15,000 working just 1 hour per week. The best part is that you don’t need to know how to code! Re-skinning apps is a pretty simple process. Basically, you purchase/create a template, change the graphics of the template, and then sell the app. The entire process will take between 1 and 3 hours depending on your experience. After having re-skinned apps for over a year now, I’ve found that the typical re-skinned app sells for between $100 and $300. However, I’ve had single re-skins that have sold for over $2,000! If re-skinning sounds like something you want to try, I would first recommend looking at Chupamobile. Chupamobile is a marketplace to buy app templates. They usually cost between $50 and $250. However, once you buy a template once, you can re-skin it an unlimited amount of times! After you decided on your first template, you’re going to need to re-skin the app. I’ve found that simplicity is the best when re-skinning apps. I typically just change the icon, colors, screenshots, text, and backgrounds of the app. I wouldn’t try to add features because this is time consuming and the return isn’t usually that great. After completing the re-skin, you’re almost finished with your first app! Now you just have to sell it on Flippa, a marketplace for buying and selling apps and websites. If this sounds like a good way to make money for you, you should definitely check out my YouTube Channel to see in-depth videos on how to re-skin apps efficiently. Also, join my Facebook Group so you can talk with other beginner re-skinners and learn from the experts too! I think re-skinning apps is a great way for teenagers to make money because there’s really not much of a time commitment and there aren’t any age restrictions either. Good luck!

Are you interested in business? Be the Boss! Start a small business. Start a lawn mowing business. Don’t mow the lawns yourself. Hire kids from your school to cut the yards. Your job as the company owner is to line up the work. Find yards to cut. Set it up so that you cut them every other week. You may pay your friends $15 to $20 to cut a yard, but you charge the homeowner $25 to $30 for the job. If you have just five kids cutting three yards a week, you make around $150 per week profit for yourself without ever breaking a sweat. It you get ten kids cutting five yards a week, you bank $500 a week. It should be really easy to grow it from there. When I was a kid I was cutting between 16 and 21 yards each Saturday, but I wasn’t smart enough to be the boss. I did it all by myself. It was so ling ago that I charged my clients $1 per yard. If you’re in an area with a lot of large trees in the yards, offer your clients leaf raking. If you’re in a snowy area, offer your clients shoveling or snow blowing. Go get some commercial building jobs like nursing homes, car lots, or small other businesses, You will be able to charge those businesses more for smaller areas. They are all busy making money and don’t have time to mow their grass. You can do the same thing with babysitting. If you are the babysitter you can only charge for your time. If you are scheduling baby sitters, you make a piece of each of their pay for the job that you set up and you are free to go have a date night instead of babysitting all night. You earn money while others are doing the labor. Have the funds automatically drafted to your bank account, or Venmo account. That way you only have to meet with the homeowners one time to make the sale. You just have to make sure the work is done correctly each time it’s scheduled. Get creative, find a need and fill it with students that work for you. Pay them a lot, take a little for yourself for finding them the work and you may be able to create a business that has enough clients that you can sell your small business for enough to pay your own way through college.

Sell your bathwater.  Thanks for this wonderful idea, Belle Delphine! Okay, for real, there are TONS of ways, and all it depends on what you like, your age, your background / where you live, and what you’re willing to commit to. Online ways: Instagram accounts - typically fan accounts or accounts where you regularly post a skill / talent of yours (e.g doing flips). Your posts need to be high quality, you have to be very active, this will take a lot of consistency and some luck, but after 2 - 6+ months you can start making money from sponsorships and deals.Sell things online on Etsy or other sites - particularly if you are artsy and good at making cheap crafts or useful objects.There are some online sites that pay you for surveys and things - be careful and make sure you are not sucked into scams though.I’ve heard about the app Sweatcoin which pays you for walking, I’m not sure whether it actually works but check out stuff like that.If you have good computer skills, websites such as Fiverr and Upwork let you do small graphic design, social media and voiceover gigsOld-school ways: Babysit - YES IT’S CLICHE but, hey, you get $$ - recommended if you like kidsPetsit - like babysitting but better. Walking dogs, taking care of pets while owners are on holiday is great, especially if you enjoy spending time with animals.Wash cars - if you live somewhere where everyone drives, start by asking your neighbours.Tutor - if there’s a subject or skill you’re proficient in, tutor little kids! The best is a language, because that is something parents often cannot provide themselves - for example, I tutor mandarin to 7–10 year old kids. Since you likely won’t have a degree you probably can’t charge more than $20 an hour, but that’s not bad for a teen.Get a job at a fast-food chain, restaurant or drink stall (depends on your age and location) - yup another teen cliche but again $$ and you may learn some useful skills.Hey, if all else fails - bathwater’s always there ;) Stay scandalous!

When I was between the ages of 11 and 14 years old, I made over $5000 walking dogs and bought my first car before I could even drive.  It may not sound like a lot, but for a young kid it definitely was and back then I think I charged $2 to walk a dog and $8 per day to pet sit (this was ~1990).  I'm not saying dog walking or pet sitting is exactly the thing that you should do, but it worked for me. I had more money than any of my friends. It could have been mowing lawns or washing cars, but both of those require more equipment (lawnmower, etc). First of all, you are your own boss in a situation like this. So you keep 100% of whatever money you make. There is nothing you have to buy or spend money on to get started, as long as you have a pair of shoes and can walk. The other nice thing, assuming you're doing this in your neighborhood is that you don't need any transportation to get to and from work. You mentioned "teenager" in the question but that's a big range and you didn't specify if you have a drivers license or not.  The dog sitting part was where I made the most money because the dog would stay at it's own house and I'd come over twice or three times a day (depending on what the owner asked for) to feed the dog and take it for a walk. It didn't take much time and I could be dog sitting 3-7 dogs at a time, all at their own homes. When you figure that most people go on vacation for 10-14 days at a time typically, it adds up. People often tipped me too. I'd bring in their mail and newspaper for them or whatever they needed. With a business like this, you also get to set your own schedule more or less. Yes, dogs need walked in the morning and evening, but there is a lot of flexibility. Plus you get some exercise, get to enjoy the outdoors and you'll meet a lot of your neighbors. Do a good job for them and they'll refer you to other friends too. There is little to no overhead. Print out some fliers on your computer and walk around your neighborhood leaving them on people's doorsteps.  I continued this little business probably until I was about 18, though I got other more traditional jobs as well. It was a nice source of income and taught me a lot.

As a Teenager I supplemented My Job at an Old Fashion Service/Gas Station while in High School by buying Broken Down Cars for $100 from Friends, and from My Customers at the Service Station. I fixed up the Cars with Discounted Parts I received as a Job Perk. After fixing the Cars for next to nothing, I detailed & Buffed the Cars making Them look as good as possible. Then listed The Cars in the Classifieds between $1,000-$3,000. Not too bad of a return for $100 for the Car, $50-$250 for Cheapo parts, a little wax, labor, and $12 for the Newspaper Ad, especially for a 16-18 Year Old High Schooler. It was great until the Damn DMV started to notice that I was literally Running an Auto Dealership out of My Parent's Home. They wrote a Cease and Desist Letter to Me saying that (last year) We have documented that You sold 19 Cars in the previous Year illegally, because I didn't have, nor was old enough to even qualify for a Dealer's License. They also said I wasn't recording the $1000s in earnings to the IRS, plus My Parent's Home was zoned Residential vs Commercial. I had at any given time 3-5 Cars for Sale Parked in front of My Parent's Home, money coming out of My ***, and the only Kid in High School driving BRAND NEW Vehicles. I'm not a Criminal, so I did Retire from that Gig at the Ripe old Age of 18 or so while still in High School... Let's sum it up like this, I fought the Law and the Law Kinda Won. LOL I also wasn't old enough to "Legally" drive a Tow Truck either, but The Cops, Traffic, and The People of Madison, WI. were just glad that I cleared the Roads after Accidents, and Jumpstarted 100s of Cars during the WISCONSIN Winters, plus I made BUKU BUCKS for Myself and The Owner of this Amoco Station without ANY complaints... The 80s were Grand (Literally).., I guess looking back at it all now at 44, I STILL Relish those Days, regardless of the DMV, I can honestly say, I got the Last Laugh... This was the way I Earned Money as a Teenager...

There are lots of ways you can make money, you just have to get creative. In this day and age, especially with the power and easy access of the internet, you can never be too young to start making money for yourself. There are many unique ways to make money as. Here are some few tips that might help. Buying and re-selling. You can find things to buy and resell anywhere, you just have to keep your eyes open. Check out local garage sales and thrift stores. Even check with your neighbors or friends to see if they have anything they want to sell, but don’t have the time to list themselves. Once you find a product you think you can sell for more than you bought, make sure to validate this by looking to see how much other people are selling your product for. There are marketplaces you can list your item on including eBay, Etsy, Facebook Marketplace, and many more. Seasonal assistant. People's lives are always busy, especially around the holidays. Simply provide a service that will give busy people some of their time back and it becomes a purchase that requires little convincing. Whether it is getting pumpkins ready to carve for Halloween, eggs ready to dye for Easter, or running to the mall to pick up that last Christmas gift there aren’t traditional services for these type of things. Get the word out in your community about how you can help, provide a good experience, and again word of mouth will take over. Bundle and sell. Imagine someone is buying a new phone and they need a case, a screen protector, and a pair of headphones. Buying all of these can be time-consuming if purchased individually. Do the hard work for them. Make sure all of them are compatible and put them together at one easy price point. Whether you are selling a bundle online or to people in your local community, selling “convenience” can be easy, fun and lucrative. Content creation. Social media is now a bigger factor than ever in the buying process, especially to teens. Brands recognize this and are doing anything they can to jump on the latest trend, while helping to promote their company. As a teen you are surrounded by the culture these brands want to be a part of 24/7. You know what your friends are talking about, what’s hot, and what’s not. This type of insight and access is extremely valuable to brands. Think about how a company could become cool in your friends’ eyes and help portray this vision to the brand, whether it is a social media post, or even a new product. Reaching out to a brand may sound intimidating but all it takes is a simple DM or email explaining your idea(s). I just hope this helps.

My parents believe that being a student should always be my and my brother’s foremost occupation. It’s for this reason that, although I begged and pleaded with them, they refused to let me get a service job. But I still wanted money, so I found other ways to get around their rule. Tutoring. I did it through a local company who would pair me up with students, but I could theoretically have just put up flyers in the local library and set my own rates.Selling old clothes. I did this through an app called Poshmark and also just talking to people around my school.Selling handmade jewelry. I used to make bracelets and earrings in middle school and sell them for a *little* bit more than they were worth.Doing people’s makeup. Once I got fairly good at it I could charge people anywhere from $15-$40 to do their makeup for events.Other ways teenagers I know make money: Photography. If you are good, you can charge kids from your school or neighborhood to take photos of them, either just fun shoots or for actual events like prom and graduation.A traditional service job. Fast food, milk tea or coffee places are the most common because most restaurants don’t hire teenage servers.Instagram. Having a public account with anything over a few thousand followers (meme/niche meme, pictures of you, photography, text posts, etc) will make your account an attractive host for sponsors, who will either give you discount codes or just pay you to promote them.YouTube. “Brand influencer” is becoming a more and more viable career option, and there are a lot of teenagers who have found fame and a job online and on YouTube.

Our kids discovered they were entrepreneurs when they were successful selling chocolate bars door to door for a school project. After 1st snowfall they knocked on doors and left info sheets offering to shovel snow from sidewalks and driveways for modest cost. They were confronted for trespassing by a different neighbour when looking after a senior's flower garden in their absence. That resulted in their names being handed out for helping with 'landscaping,' cutting grass and watering yards for vacationeers. Movie theatres here offer Saturday matinees for kids. Our kids got themselves hired on to clean a theatre, initially for free tickets, later for an hourly rate [lower than minimum because they were under 16 y/o]. In high school DS #1 proudly announced he'd been hired [Fri.& Sat. 5-8 pm] as dishwasher at a nearby, family steak house. I was really upset with the idea but it was a terrific 'real life' experience. Initially DS was given every dirty job the kitchen crew could think of! They made it clear he could end up working in a kitchen for life if he didn't 'ace - it' in school. By the holidays he was 'busing' tables, by late summer he was waiting tables for 1st seating. [He taught me how to work efficiently in the kitchen]. Best of all my 'meh' student concluded he'd better up his game and graduated in the top quarter of his group. Every 10 y/o can teach elderly 'Baby Boomers and Gen 'X,' how to use all the features of their cell phone, banking on-line and best apps. 15 y/o are problem solvers. They can find the cheapest flight and best arrival times faster than a travel agent! They could take photos and write ads for e-selling for all the stuff Kon Marie followers want to clear out for a percentage of take. Any college age student can make school year support money by learning how to operate a spray paint machine correctly. They need to be detail orientated but tape, spray and clean up is an easy business to operate.

I like to think of it in terms of your strengths. No matter what your status in life, male, female, old, young, rich, poor, black, white, you have some strengths and you have some weaknesses. Let’s look at them closely and make some assumptions: Strengths: There are lots of people willing to help you out (Much more than they will when you’re a grown adult)You don’t have a ton of responsibility or commitments just yet. That means you can risk everything you have without much repercussion.Your friends are likely in the same boat and may be willing to jump on board with you easier than when you’re an adultYour social network is stronger than most adults and your circle of influence is easier to manipulateTime - You have way more time now than you will when you’re 30. Take my word for that.Weaknesses:Credibility - Since you haven’t done a lot in your umteen years, you won’t have a lot to show, so whatever you do shouldn’t require a ton of background or experienceWealth/Starting Capital - Honestly this is over-rated. You shouldn’t need any money to make some money. But not having any cash up front can be psychologically disabling. Always keep in mind, Walt Disney didn’t have the money to build Disneyland, he still got it done.So let’s see. You need to do something that: Doesn’t require a lot of startup capital (less than $1000)Doesn’t require you to have a lot of testimonials or historyLeverages your social circle, friends and family heavilyTakes advantages of your free time effectivelyTakes advantages of your position to take bigger risksThese days there is no shortage of things that fit the above criteria. But using the above litmus test can help you determine if you’re on the right track. Some ideas that come to mind: Buying products at local auctions and selling them online (on amazon or ebay). Your $1000 investment can potentially turn into $2000-$3000 this way if you have done your research well. You have to do a lot of research to find an item category that yields high margins but it’s definitely possible.Running an etsy business. You can buy a 3-d printer, or fancy printer, or alike and produce high quality crafts for people on etsy. I know this is very possible because my mother-in-law is doing it in her late 60s.Learning web-design and creating lead generation sites for industries that are currently paying high commissions for such leads (Solar, Mortgage, Lending, …). This is more time consuming at the beginning but can definitely pay off.Producing YouTube content relevant to content ad-buyers are willing to pay good money for. This is something people don’t pay too much attention to but if you’re in it to make money, your content should be relevant to what advertiser are paying for. I like this one because it also teaches you how to produce content which is becoming more and more important.Anyway, I can go on, but that’s a start.

I’ve reviewed some of the previous responses, and they are helpful. However, I think there is a need to provide much more detail, and shed some light on other opportunities available out there. If you are teenager today, chances are that you have 1. Access to the internet, 2. mobile device, and 3. Have awareness to social media. These are all the tool you need to start reselling sneakers online. I acknowledge you might not have tons of capital, but this business model can help you acquire it in a short amount of time (if you play your cards right). Reselling sneakers has changed my life. Although I did not start as a teenager, it has brought a significant amount of extra income, knowledge in how to start a business, and how to apply stock investment techniques on other markets. This is a business opportunity that anyone can start, however, it does require work and research upfront (at least until you understand the market). If you understand trends in the sneaker market, you are a step ahead of me when I started. If you have no idea about sneakers, don’t worry, I will guide you on how to understand this culture, to be an effective reseller. I will summarize the three things you need to do to make thousands of dollars reselling sneakers. I cover this topic extensively on my blog post, where I provide a step by step walk-through on how to resell sneakers, however, I will keep it high level here. These are the 3 things that you need to follow to become a profitable sneaker reseller: Educate Yourself On the Sneaker Market first, Then Buy Merchandise:Understand which shoes give you the best resell profit. This will help you save time, and money. Familiarize yourself with selling platforms such as StockX and GOAT.Understand the sneaker market, and make sure you know what are people buying today. This TED talk on youtube from StockX founder helped me understand how big the Sneaker Market is.Understand l Demand For The Sneakers That You Are Looking to ResellEvaluate sales history, and price paid by buyers.Review social media to understand what potential buyers are saying about upcoming sneaker releases.Define Your Desired Profit Margin, And Stick To it. Do Not Sell Your Self Short To Make A ProfitIf you have a good sneaker for resell, do not resell for a quick price. This will only make you work harder to make a significant profit.Ask yourself: “Are You The Winner or The Loser In The Transaction?” This question will help you think of pros and cons to understand if the trade makes sense.Let me know guys if this helps. I have much more information, and would be happy to get into more discussions/questions on this topic.

If your criterion is lucrativeness, there’s a general way to make money that’s custom-made for minors: any illegal business. The reason is that if you get caught, the law goes much easier on minors, which is why so much of the business is farmed out to them. This is not the best way by other criteria you may have, however, because it has limited opportunity to carry over to adult life. If you want to get into a “legitimate” (i.e. legal) ine of work later on, it provides no useful job or character references. A friend has a great story about someone he met in addiction rehab. That person was not an addict, but was treated as one for purposes of getting out of legal trouble stemming from the narcotics business. Counselors were in a terrible position to have to explain to this person, a minor, that his future was dismal compared to his past, whether he tried to go legit or not. For you see, up to that point he was fabulously successful, had a great consumption-oriented lifestyle, and had great influence over powerful people for certain purposes — that is, on his say-so, he could have had his counselor killed! He was used to being treated with a type of respect that was the opposite of what those his age usually received. Yet he was totally unprepared for a “legitimate” life, which would be relatively dull, unremunerative, and in which he would be of low status. He didn’t even have much in the way of conventional education or skills — although at his age, he wouldn’t be expected to yet. Still, he would have to be receptive to gaining those skills, and making up some lost ground to do so. He’d have to leave the relationships that made him so powerful. If he instead tried to return to that world, he’d be marked by both law enforcement and gangsters as a person to watch out for, so he didn’t really have a future there. But since he wasn’t really an addict, even the possibility of continuing as an institutionalized, disabled individual was not a realistic one. He was of normal intelligence — not brilliant, not retarded. He would have a horrible and probably short life in prison were he to go that route, and his circumstances were such that he had no great information to trade that would earn him a setup in a new identity in witness protection.
