HOW TO MAKE MONEY AS A TEENAGER Well for as long as I’m concerned, you can argue but I think teenagers often have a very strong desire to spend from their pockets. So here are five ways you can start making money as a teenager. Affiliate marketing Affiliate marketing is one of the easiest ways to make money online. It is simply the model where you partner with businesses or companies ,get a unique link or code , and receive commissions when someone clicks through your link to make a purchase of the product or service. What’s even crazier is that some businesses have what we call “recurring commission”. These occurs when the service or product you promote are subscription based. This means that the person you linked to the business will be rebilled each time the subscription for the product or service expires. The rebilling therefore means that you also as the affiliate will get paid each time the subscriber is rebilled for the product or service. This is one way to start making passive income. refer one time, get paid as long as the user keeps using the service or product. Personally, this are the type of programs I go for. check out 78 Best Affiliate Programs For Making Recurring Revenue Online (2020). How then do you make the sales, Are you going to text everyone you have in your phone contact to click the link and make the sales, chances are none of them will buy. So the next thing is getting your link out to people who actually may be interested in the product you promote. One way to do this is to create content that relate with the product you’re promoting. By creating content I mean you could start something like blogging, or vlogging(video creation) that relate with the product or service you promote. For example , if you’re promoting fitness products , you can write blog posts that advice people on hot they can stay fit or tips to stay fit. You can get ideas for topics to blog about from Quora . Also you can get topics on this cool site which I’ve actually used: Search listening tool for market, customer & content research. When you get traffic to your blog, you could either send them directly to your offers or use the traffic to build a list or even do both. I strongly recommend you do both especially building a list because this means you can retarget this people later. This is called lead generation. read more about it here: Lead generation . Another place you can get your links out is on youtube, you don’t even need to create videos yourself, here’s how to get already made made videos to build your content. Go to youtubeSearch for videos about your nichefilter the videos for creative commons(Free to use for commercial without youtube penalizing you)Download the videos and reupload on you channel and add a description which should include your affiliate link.There’s nothing wrong with uploading 5–10 videos on your youtube channel before even ranking or looking for traffic. Read here how you can rank your youtube videos fast: 6 Hacks: How to Rank YouTube Videos Fast. Another hack is to use Quora to get traffic to either you blog or youtube videos, search for good questions that have a good following that are related to your niche answer questions and also drop links to your blog and also you can embed your videos which means that your video would have direct traffic and views from Quora. Quora would also push your answers up because it values visuals like videos and images now. Some affiliate marketing programs you could sign up for are : Amazon.com Associates Central, ClickBank , JVZoo etc. Print on demand business  Print on demand business is one the easiest models of business out there, given the fact that you basically don’t have to spend. All you need to do is make a design of a t-shirt and you could display it on your site or even social media profile. once there’s demand for it, you send the design for a company who’d print the designed t-shirt out and ship it out to the customer. Then you get paid as the designer. mostly the pay is at 50% depending on the company you’re dealing with. It is as easy as that and a risk free business model out there. It is also the easy way to start and e-commerce business. You can boost your sales by using influencers on your social media platform, who’re dealing with your niche. the ideal influencer for this would be ones dealing with fashion and clothing. pay them the little fee and the promote your brand to their followers which I’m sure won’t be an easy task for you to build. For this kind of business I recommend using Instagram as it is thriving on stuffs like this. Here are platforms to find influencers ready to work with you :Top Influencer Marketing Platforms to Boost your Campaigns (Updated 2020). This is one way to start a real business , I recommend you have a landing page or a blog at least where you can build your list (Lead generation) to retarget people who visit your blog or landing page. Why should you build list for retargeting? This is because research has it that 90% of those who visit a flat website don’t visit again. So it’s important to find a way to trap your visitors and keep in touch as well as market to them later. Read everything there is to know about lead generation: Lead generation. Dropservicing business  Dropservicing is similar to the famous dropshipping as a business model. But as the name implies , you are rendering servicing. personally I am a champion if this business model because it is a business I started with literally nothing. Here is how it works, for example you parade yourself as an agency that designs graphics for clients, you get a project, outsource it to freelancers who often charge way cheaper than the agreement between you and the client. pay of the freelancers and keep the big profit for doing nothing. Like dropshipping where you don’t own the product, In dropservicing too, you don’t actually render the service. Read Dropservicing. This business will literally give you passive income and you can start as small as you want to scaling up to becoming 6–7 figure earner. You could even get to a point where you run ads and getting clients through a sales funnel on autopilot without tweaking or touching anything. First you are adviced to start off with just one service so you can easily become an authority in that. You don’t need to be Jack of all trade ,pick a particular service to render for clients. You can specifically deal with facebook ads service for clients. In fact you could deal with a particular kind of business. Like running facebook ads for dentists. Sounds crazy but it one way to become the go-to for businesses like this. Freelancing  Freelancer is one of the ways you can use to make money online. Whatever skill you have, chances are there’s someone on the net looking for services from you. From easier to render services like graphic designing and logo making to web/app development. To start , you want to sign up as a freelancer in one of these : Hire Freelancers Online & Find Freelance Work , Your Access To This Website Has Been Blocked, In-demand talent on demand.™ Upwork is how.™ . Start taking easier jobs that may not actually pay as high as your dream job first in order to get some reviews and build your profile stronger. With time , you’ll be able to land those high paying jobs that would make you feel more relaxed and fulfilled. I know At least 5 freelancers who have earned $100k in a single year. So you want to go out there and build an image for yourself first, then go for the high ticket jobs. The big clients who actually spend more usually want someone with some proof of work or portfolio. Read how How To Become A Successful Freelancer: A 5-Step Guide. Dropshipping Business  Dropshipping has been around for years and has produced millionaires over the years of it’s existence. It is the business model where you set up a store and List products from a supplier and fulfill the orders when someone buys and the supplier handles the shipping while you keep the sales profit. For example you list a mug sold by a supplier for $5 as $10–$15 , when an order is made, you redirect the order to the supplier and the supplier ships the product to the buyer. The most common platforms for dropshippers to build their stores are Shopify and Wordpress. while the most common supplier of dropshipping products is aliexpress. Though most people claim the business model is long dead and replaced by the new dropservicing, it is still very much alive and people are still making thousands of dollars every month. Know what products are trending , you can do some product research and build your store based on your research. Driving traffic through the same method as dropservicing, if you have a small capital to run ads on facebook , that would help because paid ads is always a quicker way to generate sales. Conclusion These are my favorite ways anyone can jump in and start making money, notice I haven’t included stuffs like online survey. I only write about stuffs I know, I heard it easy but never tried it, not once . Besides you can not earn a living with that, perhaps good if you want pocket money. Abasiama Nyong.

Here is how I made over € 11.000 when I was 18.  N°1 Flipping items on eBay. I am Italian so the market could be a little different, but I saw American people did the same thing, so I suppose it will work for you as well. Start searching for some items on Facebook marketplace or other free marketplaces online. Here comes the big part: On eBay, you can immediately see if is worth buying an item to sell it. For example, search for “Playstation 2” and then (in the filters) click on “Sell items” eBay will show you: How many of those products were been soldThe frequency they have been soldHow much money people are paying for those itemsThat’s all you have to see for understanding if is worth it. You don’t need to buy those items, just make a listing on eBay At the moment you sell it contact the seller and tell him that the courier will get the package. N°2 I repeat the process until I have some listings so I can start investing 20% of my time in testing products in dropshipping. It means I make some listing of new products I don’t have but that I saw from other suppliers online. It’s complicated to find a product to sell in dropshipping, but once you did it, you make more profit then flipping. N°3 I would start making 3 easy listings and waiting 24 hours to see how they perform. At the same time, I continue flipping items. N°4 If one product has more than 30 visits I can keep it. If it doesn’t, I delete it and I try another item. While I’m doing this I start to understand which market niche is more interesting. N°5 At the moment I find the product that works with dropshipping I will spend €5 in Facebook ADS to make traffic on my listing. I don’t want that people buy my item, I just want a lot of people landing on my listing so my ranking on eBay will improve. The more I sell the more I spend. N°6 Repeat the process until you are good with it :)

Probably by starting a simple service-oriented business like housecleaning or lawn maintenance, taking it very seriously, and establishing a reputation for quality and reliability. It may not be a lot of money at first, but if the business is expertly managed, it will grow and can lead to what is, for most teenagers, a lot of money. 50K to 200K is easily possible within 3–5 years. The keys to success will be maintaining focus (especially as the bank account swells) and learning as much as possible about business and investment. For instance, it will be necessary to learn how to track and manage expenses; hire and schedule employees, market to obtain new business as the workforce grows, and much else besides. Understand that as a young person, you actually have a tremendous competitive advantage in that you should have more energy and a greater store of good health than someone older. That means that getting up early and working hard all day is not going to impact you all that much. You will also find that there is nothing the world loves more than seeing a young, ambitious person on their way up, and people will reward you for your success by using and recommending your services. But no matter what happens, don’t get distracted if you really want to maximize your success. This will be hard to do because as a young person, you are still at the stage where new experiences of all kind are irresistible. Expect temptation in many guises to come your way, and it is your job to avoid them if at all possible. Stay away from drugs and alcohol. Avoid people who want to go out partying all the time. Avoid people who want to borrow money. Just get up early every day, work hard and save your money, and eventually, you’ll have plenty of it.

There are several ways of making money using internet, the very powerful medium created by the wonder of programming the web.  Building websites and providing SEO services, as other's have mentioned, is one of the sure shot ways of making a good income online. If you are not built for the learning curve and wish to earn money online without having to learn the skills and technology, there are opportunities which you can take advantage of and build a phenomenal business for yourself. Incomes are of two types, linear and leverage. Linear income: Working for yourself and by yourself and if your income is based on your efforts alone, that is linear income. If you work, you generate income. If you stop working for whatever reason, you could be on vacation or down with sickness or busy attending an emergency situation or any other emergency, the income stops and the client base that you build may tend to fade away.   Leverage income: All corporations are leverage based systems. They incorporate and appoint CEO, CFO, Managers and team leaders and the entire team is monitored by board of directors. This is like an auto-pilot system where the founder's involvement is limited but will earn the dividends from the business. But the investment might be in millions of dollars and not many have that kind of money for investment. There is a less risky way of doing business and taking advantage of the same kind of auto-pilot business system. Network Marketing (also known as Multi - level marketing) is the name. On YouTube you will see several motivational leaders of very high repute and extraordinarily successful. Some of those leader's are: Les Brown, Jim Rohn, Mike Dillard and Eric Worre to name a few. These people have built very huge businesses which generated the kind of income which gave them opportunities not only to become financially successful but also gave them the opportunity to follow their passions. If we study the economic history, we have seen the industrial revolution in the past. People would join an manufacturing industry and work there for 35 years and retire from work. In the present scenario, this kind of job security no longer exists. People never know when they might be shows the exit door. No industry of jobs have a secure cover. People constantly work in fear and uncomfortable mindset scared of losing their job. We as human beings have a higher purpose in life. If a job is not what you are made for, look around and there might be other opportunities that might interest you. Selling of digital products is BIG now. With the momentum created by companies like Amazon, eBay and similar successful companies, brick and motor stores and not running as successful like in the past. People are buying almost anything on the internet. Imagine, groceries are also being delivered to people's doorsteps which options of return as well. Follow your passions and live your dreams.

It is great when teen’s take an active interest in learning how to make money. However, it should be noted that what has worked for one individual may not work for another as everyone is unique and everyone’s situation is equally unique. I think that it is great when individuals share their experiences from the standpoint of offering ideas to provide direction and perspective. However, there is always a lot of important information that is left out of such shared suggestions. This is a major reason why it is important to work with mentorship. Of course that requires one to find the right mentorship to help them successfully achieve their objectives and goals. This is important because the majority of mentors available to teens have their own agendas, ideas, and objectives. Parents what what they want what they believe is best for their teens. Schools, are trying to steer students towards, and help them find careers. And pastors, are focused on the spiritual well being of their teens. This is not bad, however, it may not be what the teen is looking for after all teens are still trying to figure themselves out at this time of life. Teens are also not always open to listening to adults much less mentors, and are not likely to be able to afford the mentorship needed to achieve their objectives and goals. Much less to help them develop the mindset and skillsets necessary to achieve a sustainable secure lifestyle, career and wealth they desire and dream about achieving. That is one of the reasons why I started Strategic Life, Entrepreneurship, & Wealth Consulting, (SLEW-C) to provide mentorship and consulting services to those who want and need it but cannot afford it. Teens can sign up at slew-c.com and receive free mentoring online. There are a lot of variables that go into suggesting applicable opportunities to teens, this is why you will not see me making suggestions to people as to what the best way to make money is. The best way for anyone to make money regardless of age and gender is to monetize your passions, interests and skills.

Today’s world opens up lots of opportunities for teenagers. The list of young successful entrepreneurs is long. There are many names like Chris Phillips, the founder of Dot5Hosting, who had made his first million by the age of 18, and, of course, Mark Zukerberg, who came into money while studying at college. The point is, all of their achievements have become possible due to the opportunities the Internet has brought about. Here are some ways you could use to make money online as a teenager: 1. Online surveys One of the easiest ways to make some extra money for teenagers is taking part in online surveys. This is the most precious thing for companies. It’s necessary to know it for improving their products and working out marketing strategies. The good news for teens is that companies need this information so much that they’re ready to pay money to find it out. Websites like Swagbucks, MyPoints and CashCrate allow you to take part in different surveys, play online games and watch videos, etc. For this, you get some points which you may trade in for cash or gift cards later. This way of making money online is the least demanding, it won’t bring you much money, though. 2. Freelance platforms Do you have a talent for writing or drawing? Enjoy doing it? Before the Internet broke the mold, your relatives could have told you off for spending your time on these tasks. Now, you could turn your passion into your bread and butter. If you can draw, write or know how to code, online platforms for freelancers open up great opportunities for you. Websites like Fiverr and Upwork give you a hand in the search of people who need your talents and knowledge. There, you may find plenty of orders including design, copywriting, web development and so on. The registration there is free. Yet, you must pay some fees from each order for using these platforms. 3. E-commerce platforms If writing and drawing aren’t your cup of tea but you’re good at creating things, then you could also make money online. You may simply sell your crafts or artworks by using online e-commerce platforms like eBay, Amazon or Etsy. The beauty of these websites is that you don’t need to look for buyers. They’re already there – these e-commerce platforms are well-known and have loads of visitors every day. However, the level of competition there is really high. And probably, at this point of your life, you don’t have efficient tools to stand out from your rivals. Anyway, if you’re sure that your products are special, you could give it a try. 4. Tutorial websites If you’re young, it doesn’t mean you can’t teach people something. Many websites are ready to hire teenagers as tutors. So, if you’ve got good knowledge of a subject, you’re welcome. You could register on the platforms like Tutor and Chegg and help people in their learning. So, if you think that teaching people is your calling, this way of making money is fit for you. 5. Dropshipping business For dropshipping, you don’t need to buy goods in advance and store them. The things you need are your website to promote the products and reliable business partner who takes care of the rest of the tasks. Not bad, right? As you’ve said you are interested in starting a dropshipping store. I firstly recommend you read this guide: How to Start Your SuccessfulDropshipping Business. Dropshipping model is profitable, easily scalable and, most importantly, affordable. Thus, even teenagers could take a stab at it. So, if you’re a teen dreaming of getting to the list of young successful entrepreneurs, dropshipping is a way to pull it off.

At the risk of sounding old fashioned, nothing wrong with earning a little sweat equity. If you live in a place where grass grows whether people want it to or not, mow yards. Not glamorous or necessarily fun, (though I certainly preferred it to any of the min wage style “teenager friendly” jobs I ever had), but that’s the good part, people will pay you well, really well, if you’re willing to do the job for them and do quality job in a reliable and trustworthy fashion. The older couple who lived across the street from me growing up paid me on several occasions to mow their yard, it was a pretty good sized yard, probably took me 2 hours of pushing a beat up old push mower around, but you know what? $60 seemed more than worth it! I could spend my entire saturday doing mind-numbing work at min wage and not make that much, plus I did it on my schedule, I got to be outside, earbuds in my ears listening to a ball game or music or whatever, and not one person interrupted me the whole time. If I had it to do over again I would have drug that old mower and a can of gasoline up and down my neighborhood making $25/hr mowing yards every weekend instead of working the lousy jobs I did. I had a buddy a year or two younger than me who did just this starting when we were in high school. Started off just looking to make some gas money, built up a decent client base over a summer through word of mouth, a year or two later had bought some pro-grade equipment and a trailer and was hiring friends of his to work for him because he had more work than he could possibly manage. By the time he was in college his lawn care business was doing well enough that I believe he was seriously tempted to quit the whole college charade and just become one of the major local businesses of this sort in our town of ~100,000 people. He ended up graduating and moving on to better things, but there are many worse ways to make some bucks as a teen than finding 3 or 4 people in your neighborhood who will pay you $40-$100 weekly to spend a few hours keeping their yards looking good. Plus you get a tan, get some exercise, and get to know the satisfaction and good night’s sleep that comes with a day spent doing physical labor.

There are many ways to make money as a teenager. Of course you could work for someone else but where’s the fun in that? Building your own business is something you should consider instead. I mean, think about it. If you start a business when you’re 15, 16 or 19 and do the right things, it’s absolutely possible for you to retire at 30, 35. Sure, you’ll have to make some sacrifices (fewer parties, wake up early during week-ends, less holidays…) but always keep this in mind : “Entrepreneurship is living a few years of your life like most people won’t, so that you can spend the rest of your life like most people can’t.” The earlier you start the better off you’ll be. So let’s see what businesses you can start when you are a teenager. Build a profitable blog  Building a profitable blog is a great way for teenagers to make money because you almost don’t need any money to start. You just need 3 things to create a profitable blog: A domain nameA hostAn email service provider (Mailchimp, Aweber, ConvertKit…)(total cost= around $40/month) Building a profitable blog is easy. All you have to do is to choose a profitable niche, build a highly engaged email list and sell your subscribers products and services they need and want. If you do that, it’s impossible to fail, trust me. Your email list is the key part of this process. It must always be your priority when building your blog. No matter what you do (create content, guest post, podcast…) you must always focus on the growth of your email list. Because with a highly engaged email list, you can make thousands of dollar every month. If you want to build a profitable blog, I recommend you to join my newsletter (it’s free). Every month you’ll learn how to create a blog, drive traffic, build an email list and more. I’d be more than happy to help you :) Build something and sell it  If you are a creative teenager and like to build stuff, you can create your own physical products and sell them on Etsy. How do you promote your stuff? Instagram. If you sell jewellery for example, go to Instagram, find influencers that love fashion and that have many followers. Reach out to these influencers and offer them your jewellery for free. In exchange, ask them to post one or two pictures of themselves with your jewellery to promote your product. Don’t forget to add the link of your Etsy shop in the description of your Instagram profile. That should make you a few thousands dollar a month. Want more? This article will inspire you. Flee market flipping Flee market flipping is also a great way for teenagers to make money quickly. The process is simple: Step 1: You go to flee markets, thrift stores or auctionStep 2: Find items that look expensive or weirdStep 3: You check the price of these items on eBay, AmazonStep 4: You negotiate the price with the vendor (that’s an important step if you overspend to get the item you’ll lose moneyStep 5: Buy the items if you are in the same ballparkStep 6: Sell the item on eBay, Amazon, Craigslist, FacebookThis guy follows these exact step and make $42,000/year working 5–10 hours a week. Hope it helps!

Here’s what I did during high school- I had a job, worked as many hours as I could fit in on the weekends, and if schoolwork was light, I’d work after practice also.Everyday I gave up my lunch block to walk across the street and walk dogs.Moving- Tons of moving. Boxes, beds, bureaus, you name it, I’ve moved it during high school. People are always moving, and once you get a reputation as someone who can move stuff, you’ll get referred to others.Yard work- This one is pretty straightforward, and depending on your geography is more or less available.Random tasks. I answered a question recently where I told the story about how I dug up and replaced a drainage system in a driveway. Stuff like that always needs to get done. I started getting those jobs after I sent out a few emails letting people know I could do things for them.It’s really not that hard to make money as a teenager, you just need to make it a priority. To have a job I had to give up hours of hanging around aimlessly. I had to give up the social time of every school day. I got some calluses on my hands, dirt on my shoes, and sore backs on many Monday mornings after a weekend of various jobs. I also had to just get over my fear of “cold-emailing”. A lot of people think, “Well, I don’t have those opportunities.” Well if you make it a priority, and you figure out what exactly is preventing you from that (Are you afraid of reaching out for people? Do you need to get a work slip signed? Do you want more time with your friends?). Best of luck to all, hope that helped.

Well, making money is a destination that has numerous routes, and one may come up with a lot of options ahead of the existing usual suspects.  Image Courtesy: How To Mint Money Teenager or not, making money is the same for everyone. All you need is an undying passion with a clear goal, and the ability to work hard, irrespective of the countless obstacles you may face. Coming to the point, as I said before, there are plenty of ways for one to make money, and in a legal and transparent way. I’ll list down a few easy ones that won't take any investment to begin with. A Blog : Starting a blog is the easiest way to start generating revenue. A blog can be about multiple topics (Buzzfeed) or about a particular niche (Codename Apple). Either way, the content you create would help you build a massive user base in time, with which you would be able to generate revenue. The most successful ones make six digit revenues a month.Internships : Interning is one of the easiest way to earn some money, and it could open up a whole new world of endless possibilities and opportunities. You may earn some stipend to begin with, and eventually you stand a great chance to get employed in the same company, full time. You could also be exposed to brilliant minds within the company, and you may find yourself in a pool of new opportunities or as a co-founder of your own new company with one of them.Affiliate Marketing : This is an area which is very well connected to a blog, and your expertise in a niche could help you earn money by selling products in that niche. For example, Codename Apple generates its revenue with Amazon Affiliates, and is doing really well. Once you have a decent user base, you need not worry much about generating revenue; for the visitors would be doing the job themselves. This is far better than advertising, and even blogs with low visitor count do extremely well in this area.Write a Book : This one may take up quite a bit of time, but if you have the writer in you with an imaginative mind, start penning your thoughts immediately. Make up a wonderful story, or write about something that you are knowledgable and passionate about. It can be about relationships, technology, a war thriller, a ‘how to make money’ guide or anything. Next, get it to a publisher, get it published and cross your fingers. If it becomes a best seller, you might find yourself become a millionaire!Freelance : I cannot stress this point enough. This is not just for teenagers, but for anyone who wishes to make money. If you have a skill, advertise it, work, and make money. The best way to start would be to have a word of mouth publicity. Also, you could sign up for freelancing websites like Freelancer, Upwork and Fiverr and start making money quickly. This can be done from the comfort of your home and elsewhere, and you could make a lot of money with this. You might as well freelance full time!YouTube : Become a YouTuber! All you need is a video camera, and the ability to speak in front of it. Pick up a niche, and start right away. Once you have a significant number of views and subscribers, monetise the channel. It would take time, but it would boost in case you went viral!Surveys : Websites like Valued Opinions pay you to take part in their surveys, which is an easy way to make money online.You also have other ways to make money, which might take a bit more expertise and capital to begin with. They are: The Next Big Thing : An idea, which might change or disrupt an entire industry. Probably the next Facebook, or the next Dropbox. Or a completely new animal in itself. There is no limit to this, just an idea. Develop and evolve, and make it the next unicorn!Consultancy : Consultancy has been a dark horse in this world, and this is a tremendous way to generate a lot of money. The only things you need to succeed in this is incredible knowledge coupled with skills and the right contacts. It is difficult at the beginning, because you won’t be trusted because of your age. But gradually, this will improve, and you may be making tons of money.I hope this solves your query. My best wishes. Thank you for the A2A, Rohit Dixit Cheers!

Set up shop in school. Most of the schools beyond elementary that i have seen are nearby a convenience store of some type. Schools also generally have a policy that once you are on campus, you must remain there (at least at lower grade levels) and so students who are bussed in are not allowed to cross the street to spend that sweet sweet pocket cash. You, a student who either arrives by foot (on a path of their own choice) or via parent (with a drop off spot arranged off campus) can be the link that people need to get their fix of Pringles, or Gummi Bears, or Dip Stix, or whatever ridiculous thing that your friends are into throwing money at. Hey a year ago, the market across from my school couldt keep fidget spinners in stock. Every morning someone would come in and but 10 or more. They would sell them for a buck more at school, and repeat the process. Even if you are a kiddo trapped on campus, it doesnt mean you can’t serve the demand. Trips to your local market at night can get you the stock of goods that your less forward thinking classmates might really want after that 3rd period math class. You might even find a wholesale supplier is available, and then come real profit margins! Short answer, it doesnt matter how old you are. Buying low and selling high will always be a good business, as long as you can either create, or at least serve the demand. Note: Check your school policies before starting this full force, while it is unlikely that it is against the rules to sell items, it may be against the rules for you to have them in certain locations, and your choice of items could come under scrutiny. Keep it school safe!

There is no one way to make money in this world but I want to share with you the way that I think is the most practical, time efficient and has the greatest return on investment out of everybody’s suggestions. This answer can be a resource for anyone and everyone looking to make a few hundred extra bucks on the weekend. As opposed to teaching you how to turn $100 into $1,000 or even $10 into $1,000, I’m going to teach you how to turn $0 into $1,000. It’s called the Craigslist “free” section. Step 1: Go to Craigslist  Step 2: Under the “for sale” tab, there’s a section called “free”. Click that.  Step 3: The “free” section is where people list stuff that they want to get rid of; anything from an old couch or desk to an extra TV or set of dishes. Find someone with something that they don’t want and that you think you could sell.  Step 4: Drive to the spot where they want you to pick it up (or take the bus if you don’t have a car).  Step 5: Take their thing.  Step 6: Go back home.  Step 7: Take a picture of it.  Step 8: List it on Facebook Marketplace.  Step 9: When someone buys it, give it to them.  Step 10: Rinse, Repeat and start making money on the weekends: I’m already anticipating someone to comment and say “well, it’s going to take you 40 minutes to go pick it up, 40 minutes to get back home, and then 7 minutes to list it on Facebook Marketplace,” but here’s the thing, what are you doing with your time anyways? You’re watching the fucking Spurs game. So, sure, it may take you 87 minutes to make that extra $20, but trust me, that’s a whole lot better than doing whatever it is that you’re doing otherwise. I really think that you can make an extra $300 a week. If you’re taking you 6:00 PM to 9:00 PM on Monday and Tuesday to go pick stuff up, then listing it online throughout the week, and having people come to your house on Saturday to buy whatever you have listed, it honestly could end up being more than $300 a week. Don’t believe me? Here is a video of me going through the same process I’m telling you to do:  Hope this helps!! There are lots of options for a lot of different people. It widely varies based on your goals.Level 1: Commodity There's the requisite lawnmowing and babysitting that's really common for teenagers. You can tutor people, which I enjoyed. You can get the part-time retail job or restaurant job that so many people get as young adults.  What I'd actually recommend is starting your own business. While you're a teenager, you don't have to worry about subsisting on Ramen while your startup gets off the ground. Depending on which state you are in, it can be as simple as filing a few forms online to start a business; when I was in high school, it took me less than 30 minutes to go from nothing to a full-fledged business in the state of Indiana. Level 2: Jason Fried and Audiofile I decided to figure out how to make my own. I got FileMaker Pro (I paid for it with the stash I'd saved up selling stuff to my friends) and started messing around. After a few months, I had solved the problems I had with organizing my music. I knew what music I had, where it was, whom I had loaned it to, how much I paid for it. The solution was elegant and easy to use. I called it Audiofile. Most of the music-collection products on AOL's file section were freeware. Download them, install them, and you don't owe the author a dime. There were a few shareware options (you pay if you use them, but it's mostly an honor system), but most were free. I'd already learned that I really enjoyed making money. And I thought that Audiofile was good. And even then, I thought that if something was good, then it was worth paying for. So before making it available to other AOL users, I added a limit in the program—people could file 25 CDs for free; after that, it would cost $20 to unlock Audiofile and remove the limit. I remember my first customer. One day my parents gave me an envelope. It came from Germany and had those airmail stripes at the top. I opened it up, found a screenshot of Audiofile printed on a piece of paper—and a crisp $20 bill. More envelopes rolled in. Over the next few years, Audiofile probably generated $50,000—not bad for a kid in college in the early '90s. The lesson: People are happy to pay for things that work well. Never be afraid to put a price on something. If you pour your heart into something and make it great, sell it. For real money. Even if there are free options, even if the market is flooded with free. People will pay for things they love. From How to Get Good at Making Money Solve a problem that should be solved. Level 3: 4Snaps How a Florida kid's "stupid app” saved his family’s home and landed him on the main stage at Facebook Michael Sayman is an interesting case. It's worth thinking about what he's done thus far if you are a teenager who would also like to be making money.

So here is how you earn money as a teenager.  CREATE VALUE.  Creating value at a small level isn't hard. When I was ten I stared cutting my grandmas lawn. It took me 30 minutes. It would have taken her 3 hours to do the same amount of work. Therefore, I got $25, about three hours pay instead of 30 minutes.  Why? Because I created three hours of value!  Fast forward to my teens, at 12 I taught myself HTML and CSS. I began responding to wanted ads on Craigslist for a web designer. The first site I did for someone I charged $80. It took me nearly two weeks to complete, but it was well worth it. A year later I ended up giving the guy all his money back and thanking him for a great learning experience.  Within about six months, I controlled 40% of all web design gigs on the NYC computer gigs craigslist and my name was starting to get referrals. I remember when I was employed by a big time Manhattan psychologist. When I looked at his rates, he charged nearly $500 an hour. My rates at the time were only $35. He told me that he would give me $300 an hour if I made his site a priority.  Why did he give me $300 an hour? Because it would have cost him nearly $1,000 to just setup a simple Godaddy website (2 billable hours).  So in the end, CREATE VALUE FOR SOMEONE WHOSE TIME IS WORTH MORE THAN YOURS.

1) START A BLOG: Blogging is a popular and very versatile way of earning money while having fun. Many people may think of blogging to be hobby, but there are plenty of ways to monetize it. You can blog about almost anything and everything. It may be something you specialize in or are interested in, it is also a great way to share your passion. There are multiple online courses and books to help you get started.  2) BECOME A FREELANCE WRITER: If you have a flair for writing, you can start your own service online or in the neighborhood. You can write for startups or small companies near you. Alternatively, you could make a resume online so that companies and startups can contact you for your talent.  3) TUTOR: This is a very popular and effective way of helping others as well as having fun yourself(and of course earning). You can teach a subject that you are interested or good in. You can tutor younger students in math, reading and science or you can teach an older age group other skills such as a foreign language, coding, painting, anything you like and are good at!  4) HAVE A BAKE AND SELL: This one is quite self explanatory, all you have to do is mix up your ingredients and create your favorite delicacies. You can call over friends or family to help or even hold a baking competition in the neighborhood! This is good to raise money for a cause too.  5) START A YOUTUBE CHANNEL: This is a great idea if you have a lot of ideas to showcase and are good in front of a camera. However, it is not necessary that you be in front of the camera, you can make animated videos or have slide shows. YouTube is the easiest way to earn money, all you need is a total of 10,000 views or 1000 subscribers on your channel.  SELL HANDMADE DIYS: You can make anything you think will be useful to others, and sell it! It can be anything; jewelry, greeting cards, purses, notebooks, bookmarks, anything you made yourself. You can check out sites likeEtsy to sell your creations.  7) USE YOUR TALENT: Everybody has a special skill whether you've mastered it or it's still waiting to be discovered. Either way you can use your talent or skills to make money, you can sell the products you make, teach that skill to someone else or provide services using your talent. It can be anything; painting, coding, linguistics, sewing, making music, you can even do voice overs or podcasting if you have a good voice! Now that you're filled with ideas, there is nothing left to do but start!

I wish I knew more details, such as your age and education. First, get real. You are not going to be a millionaire by the end of next week.  The only way you are going to make any money is to get a job. You will not make big money. More in the order of spending money, which should be just perfect for a teenager. Think about how many hours per week you are able to work. What kind of work are you willing to accept? All of your life you have been surrounded by people who work. Everywhere you go, you are in the midst of people who are doing jobs. But you probably didn't think of it that way. Every time you walk into a store, restaurant, theater, school, mall, parking lot, and web site you are surrounded by people at work. What have you seen out there in the world that you think you could do? Are you talking about a summer job? A great summer job is to be a camp counselor. The pay sucks, but you can have a fun summer, make a small bit of money, and learn a lot about responcibility. Do you want a "permanent job" that you can do weekends or evenings while you finish high school? Fast food delivery might be good, and you might make extra money on tips. I assume you are in school. Many high schools have a job board. If yours does, (usually in the counseling office) see if there is anything there that interests you. If your school does not have a job board, talk to the head counselor about starting one. Let local newspapers to know about it, and ask them to post articles about the student job board. Do you or your family know someone who owns a business? If so, approach that person and see if they have a job that you could do. Personally, I have had many kinds of jobs during my career. I have been working ever since I turned 16. My first job was in a local pharmacy delivering and stocking shelves. My parents knew the owner. My next job, still during high school was doing the same kind thing, at a local liquor store.  Some of the other jobs I had during college were working on a loading dock, (hard physical work, too hard for me), waterbed salesman, janitor - (another aweful job, I quit after 2 weeks), medical insurance billing clerk, phone solicitor, assistant to an electrician, and bill collector jobs. Some jobs I liked, some I hated. Some I did well at. Some I didn't, and got fired a few times. Here's what I learned from all those different jobs. All work is dignified. I also learned that nobody ever pays you more than the value of what you do. I also learned that I didn't want to be a minimum wage nobody for the rest of my life. I learned to have ambition. But I also knew I was going to remain "a minimum wage nobody" until I could make get an EDUCATION.  So work hard, and stay in school. And have respect for everyone who works hard and does a good job, no matter what they do.

Earn money with yout skill. As a sophomore, I am alway tight with money. I know where my money runs. It is Taobao, a online shopping platform, swallowing my money as a monster since I started to use it. Studying in Chinese public college, my tuition is not very expensive. But in private ones, it is another story. I pay about 6700 yuan per year for tuition and accommodation. It is 950 dollars or so that I can get into the college. More fortunately, my parents as most of Chinese parents send money to support their children. But I still lack money. Once month, I even had no money to eat lunch. I felt shamed to ask money from my parents, because it was just half of the month. I told myself, "look the bright side, it is the perfect time to lose some weight." I was trying to hide my financial embarrassment, but what failed me was my phone out of credit. At that moment my dad topped up for me and called me why. So I decided to earn money myself. I had had many part-time jobs. But I was so sick of the time-consuming and tedious jobs which there was nothing to learn from. One day my friend who was my savor got a job for me. It was to help foreign models and Chinese photographers communicate. Because my major is English, and my speaking is good. When asked the salary I expect, I didn't really mind. I considered it as memorable experience I would really enjoy. But it quite surprised me that they offered 300 yuan per day. My lord, It was a good money for a college student. I could sustain with it until the next month’s money given day. That night when I got my work done and came back. I called my parents saying, "it is my first time to realize that earning money is that easy." I laughed and thanked myself for how hard I worked on English speaking. I spent my whole freshman year practicing speaking. Every single day, I woke up and I practiced. Many of my classmates turned their noses up with it. Because speaking is always subordinate to other skills such as reading and writing. 300 yuan changed my situation in the mouth. I was transformed from being in the slum to in the city center. Moreover, I proved myself. So your skill is the best way to earn money. I mean easy and good money.

First of all, you need the understand the simple concept below: People want value, therefore people will pay for value. But only for good value. Hence, money can be made from supplying this good value to the demand that exists for it. Therefore, provoking the question: "Are you both willing and able to provide the good value that people are willing to pay for?" I believe you are already willing if you have asked this question, but are you able? This refers to if you have the skills or the ability to provide the value that people are looking for. For example, everybody may want to be the best stockbroker on Wall Street, so they are all willing, but they may not have the necessary skills to be a top stockbroker, thus they are not able.  In order to make money, you absolutely must have both the willingness and the ability to provide this value. Now, you have two choices: (a): You can give value (b): You can create value   Choice (a): Giving value. This is effectively doing a job for someone else. You are giving value to your boss by doing that job because you are helping to keep the company running, making life easier for him and allowing him to focus on other things without having to juggle so many things at once. The boss rewards this value that you are providing him with a pay check. That's the basic idea behind giving value to others.  As a 15 year old, there are two aspects of how you can give value to others in terms of jobs. I have split it up into two subheadings which I call "Homework jobs" and "No Homework jobs". A "No Homework" job is something that usually does not require a specific skill set or past experience that you need to learn or pick up beforehand, you don't have to do any prior "Homework". "No homework" jobs would include stuff like flyer distribution, washing dishes, waiting tables, lawn mowing, car washing etc...As you should be able to notice, almost anybody should be able to walk into these type of jobs. These are the kind of jobs you'd do if you need a quick buck, but not necessarily providing a long term job with constant pay. A "Homework" job is something that needs a specific skill set that brings value to the company, you need to have done your "Homework" beforehand to be able to get into these jobs, so not anyone can get into these ones. Examples of jobs in this category that could be viable for someone like you would be something like Web or App Development and Graphic Design. I personally prefer jobs like these, as you need to self learn these skills but they will stay with you, give you great experience especially working in a company and benefit you for the rest of your life and will also be in demand for the foreseeable future (Many people are lazy to learn something like computer programming so they hire). Also, if your objective is money-making, these jobs pay rather well as the value you provide here is absolutely vital. Obviously there are other ways of giving value such as helpful YouTube videos or writing good content blogs which will also generate you some money however I won't digress to that. If you are really willing enough to make some money this way, you will read up about it, though if you have any further questions you are more than welcome to message me. Choice (b): Creating value. This is effectively starting your own business. You are creating value because you are making something that is of value to people who will want to buy it. Zucks for example, created value by starting Facebook which therefore has allowed people around the world to connect, all of this value he has provided is reflected in his $35b + net valuation.  As User-10093830047695287416 brilliantly mentioned in this thread, starting your own business gives you great experience and respect, and I'd second that any day.  Thanks Tyler and make sure you follow him too, great content and value coming from his answers. If you are someone who likes to solve problems for the world or consider yourself a creative person, choice (b) would be perfect for you. The journey and things you learn along the way are priceless and if you are successful it can also be extremely financially rewarding. In terms of starting a business, people like to say how it is very hard and there are a million and one things you need to know. I personally disagree. All you need to get a business going is an idea first. How do you think of ideas? Look around you, think of the problems in this world, how could you solve them? How could you make people's lives easier? How could you create some good value? Try and get into the habit of writing down 10 ideas a day, it doesn't need to be great, just list it down, you can decide later. Thanks James Altucher for that lovely advice. Once you have gotten an idea in mind, you need to execute. Sales and Marketing, extremely important, read up and learn some of that stuff. You need people to know about your business and you also need people to buy from you after they know about what you offer, because that's how you make money.  How you will market and how you will sell, that's something you'll have to figure out yourself and what works for you because one of the lovely things about entrepreneurship is that there are no rules or textbooks, there are an infinite ways to for you to do business. You'll have to be innovative and find a way that is both effective and works for you and the company I have written similar answers below on this question before so check them out if you wish as they cover different aspects and angles and go into detail including some businesses you can start, my own experiences and reflections on what I did. There are a lot of ways to make money as a teenager. You an do odd jobs to earn cash in your spare time. Some ideas on how you could do this are:- Washing carsCutting grassBaby sittingDog walkingYou could also get a Saturday job, for example waiting on tables. You could also sell some of your old bits and pieces on Ebay or Amazon marketplace to bring in some cash. Alternatively you could earn money online. This is the best way and as a teenager you will no doubt find this easy to do. It can fit around school and there is the potential to earn far more money online than you could get doing the above tasks. The best way to earn money online (and many teenage are doing this very successfully) is through affiliate marketing. The way that affiliate marketing works is that you promote products online and when sales are made, you earn commission. The sellers give you unique links to use, so that they know you have driven the sale. There are many great companies who offer affiliate programmes such as Amazon. It is very easy to make Amazon sales because many people already know and trust Amazon and so would not hesitate to buy from them. There are many items that you can promote on Amazon and if you want to, you can promote higher ticket items such as BBQ grills, premium watches and handbags, which will earn you good levels of commission for the same amount of work. The more work you do, the more your online presence builds and your income also builds with it. The key skill to master with affiliate marketing is getting enough good quality (i.e. interested and ready to buy) traffic to your offer. However with so many communities, groups and forums online it is easy to go to where interested traffic is, and send good volumes of it to your affiliate offers. In fact, due to the massive volume of traffic on the internet affiliate marketing has never been easier to do. That being said, you will need some guidance in order to choose profitable niches and learn how to make good levels of sales. Driving traffic is also an area where I recommend you will need a bit of training to get you going effectively. Otherwise you may find that you struggle to make money at first and give up. There are some links to the very best training in my bio. One link will take you to entirely free training and information resources (Freebies) and the other (Learn from Experts) will take you to immediately downloadable video courses that cost a few dollars (around $11 ish) but are more comprehensive. If you start affiliate marketing now you will easily be able to continue with your earnings as you travel the world after college and you may also find that you don't ever need to get a 9–5 job as affiliate marketing, if done well, can bring in far more money. It also allows you to keep your freedom and does not require you to work for anyone else. I wish you all the best in your endeavours to earn money - if you have any questions at all that I can help you with please leave a comment and `I will respond. Lydia

I am going to share a method to start your own profitable business that has worked for me in the past and I have a lot of confidence in the method. It will require some upfront work, but if you put in the work 6-12 months down the road you will be happy you did. This strategy requires: Little to no technical knowledgeNo coding or SEO knowledgeNo experience with running a website beforeAround $100 in start up cash (you could invest more or less)In short, the idea will be to create a website that promotes/reviews products that have an affiliate program, rank in Google for keywords related to these products and then sell the website for a million (or close to it). The steps are pretty simple: Pick an evergreen nicheThis means a niche that will always be around and is not going anywhereYou want to work in niches that will always have demandGo to Amazon and find as many products within this niche as possiblePut all of the products into an excel spreadsheet w/ a link to the product pageTry to group the products together by product type. For example, in the food niche you would put all of the blenders together and all of the coffee makers togetherTry to find at least 100 products. The more the betterSnag a domain name that fits with your niche and create a wordpress blogWrite product reviews for each product in your spreadsheetTry to have each review be 1000+ words eachTry to write at least product review per week. The faster the better!Once you finish writing all of the product reviews you can expand into broader topicsFor example, write a review article based on your product topics that formed earlierThis is where you would write “The Best Smoothie Blenders in 2016” type of articlesDo this for all of the different product types that you haveDo this for 6–12 monthsIf you can consistently write a new article at least once a week you will see nice growth over a 6–12 month periodThe most important part is to consistently write new contentAfter 12 months you should be making a good chunk of money each monthAt this point you should try to find more products that you missed the first time and keep trying to add new content as much as possible.This money will be passive as you would have already done all of the hard work of writing all of the content and you can now just rake it in.You can continue to make passive income each month OR sell the site for 20–30x monthly profitThe amount of time you can spend on this can vary. If you want to spend as little time as possible, then I would suggest outsourcing your content articles. If you have any questions about this strategy let me know, I would be happy to help!

The best answer I can give is the one that most ppl you have talked to probably give you. Get a part time job. I think you may actually be asking for suggestions on what type to get. Look at your hobbies and interests. Do you take dance lessons? Ask at dance schools about teaching preschool and you g children’s classes. In to soccer? Apply for jobs with the soccer summer camps. Look at what you think you might want to do as a career. Are you good at creative writing and thought of being a journalist or writer? Get an entry level part time job at a newspaper or magazine. Whatever field you think of, there are part time jobs and paid internships all over that field. Now, what if you don’t really have any hobbies or interests, you just want to make money. Enter the McJob. It’s not as bad as ppl let on. Their pay is good with regular wage increases. The time is very flexible ( which is really helpful for high school and University students) and if you start now, you could be a manager by your first year University. ( like 2 of my students) they also have scholarships you can apply for and if you don’t go to uni but become a asst. manager and up, I believe they will pay for courses for further education classes if those skill can be applied to your position. Some Other fast food places and large national retail businesses do that too. Ask your school counsellor or look online for help writing your resume. There are sooo many options. The world is your oyster!

Of course there is! Now, you could aim to make thousands without putting any real effort in. I would recommend a side hustle/job that builds your skills. Whether it is social skills, marketing skills, physical skills or even positive mindset skills, make sure you’re taking something away from this rather than just money!  CAR WASHING AND LAWN MOWING. This is a perfect option for those looking for a bit of hard graft that is rewarding in the process. The best bit? You decide your working hours! Some people are also willing to pay up to $30-$40 for one job; so do 2 jobs a day (with an average pay of $10) and that’s a monthly pay of $600! That’s summer sorted. Most people will be okay to supply their lawnmowers too so you don’t need to worry about buying one yourself (unless you’re making this a part-time job).SQUADHELP. Now its time for a more lucrative strategy. Squadhelp is a website where companies give money away for business name ideas, logos and other designs. This is in the form of a competition and the winning applicant with the best idea gets the prize pot (which can be up to $250). If you have a knack for creativity and imagination, then this is the one for you! Think this one is going to be too hard to do? Have a look at the best winners for the month: The top member made almost $50,000 in over 1 year of being on Squadhelp. A lot of her money comes from selling domains and logos which you can view via the link Earn Online By Brand, Business Name , Tagline Ideas Suggestions. The domain/logo part is mainly for budding graphic designers but the name idea competition is available to everyone. You will have to go through a selection process where you will be asked to give your own ideas to some tester businesses. For example, one draft might be a ‘tech business for 16–18 year olds’. I then submit my own idea with a reason why its so good. Let’s take a look at something I made myself: Name idea: FuzeWyre Submission Explanation: FuzeWyre is the perfect name for a company like yours. With techy synonyms like ‘Fuse’ which has been stylised as ‘Fuze’ and ‘Wire’ which has also been stylised as ‘Wyre’. Both words have connotations of connection and link-building which is what the online technological world is all about. The stylisations on both words appeal to the target audience too as it has been proven adolescents prefer business names with misspellings. It is also under 10 letters long and is therefore much easier to remember. Submit about 5 of these to the best of your ability and you have much a better chance of being accepted to apply in future competitions. All you need to do is win 2 big competitions a month and you have netted yourself $400. Perfect. 3. SURVEY. This option is a little less effort than the other two options. Entering data for surveys can earn you quite a little bit of cash although you’ll need to do quite a few surveys in order to get up to the cash flow of other side hustles. This one can be a bit boring and low value-for-money but it requires very little effort and time so if you’re looking for only an extra $50/month with very little legwork, this is the dream hustle. Survey Junkie is probably the best site to indulge your survey-answering needs. There are, however, far more profitable money-making ways out there. Affiliate marketing, matched betting and domain flipping are some to name a few. These are ALL covered in the blog post 15 Easy Ways To Make Money As A Teen. Not only does it mention quite a few unheard of methods but they go into extreme detail too (especially with their 101 affiliate marketing guide!). Be sure to check it out! Hope this helped Cam

First of all, write up a resume, it doesn't matter if you don't have any experience in an actual job before, you can easily just waffle on about what sports/activities you participate in, your personal skills and abilities or whatever. It really does not matter: Employers who are looking for teenager workers are more interested in how cheap you are, and if you are available to work the hours they need. It also helps when you happen to hand in your resume at a convenient time when they are desperately looking for workers. Of course, its pretty difficult to tell when that time is, it all comes down to luck. So yeah, start from there, it doesn’t matter if you haven't found your passion quite yet, its just never a bad idea to gain some experience and skills and earn a bit of dosh on the side while still searching for your true passion. Even when you have found what you are really interested in, an employer in that field would be looking to see if you have had experience in a working environment before or not, regardless of how relevant that type of work is. However, if you really are that dedicated and willing to put in a lot of hard work, the best way to earn millions of dollars without working for somebody else is by starting your own business, developing a new idea (an app or a new kind of technology or something), or inventing something. Its a bit of a gamble, as you are putting so much effort into something which may or may not be a complete failure. Anyway, good luck. Hope you find something well-suited for you and in the meantime can find a decent part-time to earn a little bit of money. Some is better than none hey?

Talk to people. All you have to do is get involved and find a creative way to make money off every situation. I made close 750 dollars in the last 2 months at my highschool from making deals. For example, I heard someone talking about air soft guns in class. They said they wanted one but no one will take them to get one. I told him I will get him the air soft gun he wants for 100$. He was excited with my offer. I bought the gun on Amazon for 65$. With a 2 minute conversation and 3 clicks, I made 35$. I bought stun guns wholesale on the Internet and sold them to people at my highschool. I made 15$ profit off each one I sold. I bought mason jars for 1$ each and turned them into redneck wineglasses with candle stick holders an epoxy. I sold them online for 15$ each. I profited over 200$. I bought my friend a list full of things on Amazon and he payed me 115$ for what costed me 80$. All you have to do is communicate with people. See what people want and buy it wholesale, sell it retail. There is no "magic system". Just be smart about it. All you have to do is think outside of the box.

If you are mechanically inclined offer to replace lights on vehicles. Just about every light on cars are easy to get to and easy to swap out. Stay focused on the cheaper vehicles as I have come across a Cadillac that takes probably 30-60 minutes to remove the entire front facia to spend a minute to replace the headlights.  Headlights for most cars can range from 15 and up. Most blinkers, brake lights, tail lights, license plate lights can all be bought for 5 bucks for a two pack.  Charge 10 bucks for the labor of installing the bulbs. If you install 2 or more just ask for 20 bucks labor.  Remember to look for cars like Toyotas, Scion, Honda, Kia, Chevys and Fords and the likes.  Heck with the non headlights you can even charge a flat rate of 20 bucks. Then even if you replace one blinker, you've made 15 bucks. It shouldn't take more than 15 minutes to replace. Confirm at your local auto parts store that the prices for the majority of the bulbs will be 5 bucks. Also let the customers know that these prices can vary, but are the typical cost. So if you can get to where swapping out a light is done in 5 minutes or less and getting paid 15 bucks for it. That is really good money. I mean very good, cause if you assume that you had cars backed up waiting for a bulb change for an hour than you can make 180 bucks per hour. So even if you only change a few a day or hour it's still pretty good money, for easy work that hasn't taken much of your time. Good luck.

My son wanted a new dirt bike one summer and I don't just arbitrarily spend thousands of dollars on whims of my children, so I told him he would have to earn part of the money in order to have it. This insured he would maintain his interest in it and not move on to other wants, and if he did all the better. Also, it would teach him the value of money as I often did, and I know he treated things he worked for better as well. So to get to the point I told him to go with me to Home Depot where we purchased some spray paint and number stencils. From there we went to a few of my rental properties and applied the addresses on the curb. I paid him $10 per rental home and after he and his friend drove to all the rentals they proceeded to knock on doors and charge homeowners for the service where they earned between $10 and $15 per home and would earn around $200 to $300 per day. Not a bad income for a days work at 16. That would be my advice to perform a service that pays well and will allow you to save up for the photography equipment. My son had saved up $1000 in under 3 weeks with spending part and putting 10% into his savings account which I also required. He had his dirt bike in less than a month, learned a new skill that paid well, saved a few hundred in the bank, had spending money and I got to pay out several thousand for his bike. Not a bad deal, hope you find your way to getting your equipment. If you make it your #1 priority you will.

Here are some ideas that I used myself: The no-brainers:  local grocery. I started carrying bottles and cleaning the shop the day I turned 13Company cleaning. Know someone with a small office in you neighborhood? They will need weekly cleaning Delivering as postman or newspaper boyBabysitting can be especially relevant if you are a femaleThe ones I think is more fun: Work with your entrepreneurial sideDo you do something for fun that you are really good doing? If this is the case you can most likely make money on it. It is just about thinking where in the value-chain there is money to make.I used to be good at building and maintaning mopeds when I was 15. This was great fun and I started buying 2nd hand parts with a local specialist - selling it for a premium to the moped-guys in school. Services: Does your neighbors need any service (gardening/cleaning/computer help etc)? Start with a couple of  flyers for your local community and things may take off - you may be able to hire some of your friends if demand are high enough.TutoringIf you become good at a couple of courses in school you will be able to sell your hours to some that actually need your help. This will bring your academic skills and interaction with 'clients' to a new level.

Back in 98, 99, 2000-ish, myself and a few other friends had our own ways that provided us easy, and significant cash, considering our age at the time. The handful of us that did so, also happen to be the more driven individuals 17 or 18 years later. We all found a product or similar ‘replacement’ (best I can put it) that high school students had a fair to high demand for. None of these were necessarily ethical however so depending on your perspective…. free market principles, value sold is in the consumer’s eye, copyright infringements, etc. i respect your personal and all opinions. The only thing I regret is if we hurt the small business owner. My approach was selling ‘knock off’ Oakley’s. They weren’t just popular at the time for athletics but for fashion just as much, if not more. $90 to $140 for a pair to a high school kid was a stretch. I had a relative in NY. At approximately $4 per pair (very similar to the real product), my cost (in bulk purchases), I then sold them out the trunk of my 1993 Grand Am for approximately $30/pair. Again, I’m not saying it was right, even though I’m also catching myself bragging a bit, but it worked. On a side note, you can argue the price per production/outsourced labor to produce, vs. the profit redeemed if you want. I won’t go into the ventures that my friends took on. All had one thing in common though…. we identified a product or service that our peers wanted, but they couldn’t afford them. We found a solution.

Something to consider: do you have an interest in computers?  If so, I would encourage you to get to know the people who work in the I.T. department at your school. Just say that you're interested in computers, and you were wondering if they knew about anywhere you could go to learn more about them. I.T. professionals at schools are often very busy (and a bit introverted), so it might take a couple of tries, but, in my experience, they're very nice people who love it when students show an interest in/appreciation for their work.  They also might be willing to point you in the direction of a job in the field, or even offer you one. One of my favorite jobs as a teenager was at my middle school's I.T. department. Under the supervision of the department, I cleaned, repaired, and updated the school's computers. Make no mistake--it was physically demanding, sometimes boring work--but it was incredibly fulfilling to know that I was finally doing something valuable to someone other than myself, and learning useful skills in the process. Plus, with all the skills I learned and money I made, I could build a serious gaming PC after only a few weeks on the job.  I've also had a few friends who worked for small software firms while still in high school. This one took a bit more planning and foresight. Generally, they took one or two summer classes in programming before they could land an unpaid internship somewhere. After their unpaid internships, they could often make $15-25 per hour working at software companies or freelancing.
