Imagine yourself 10 years in the future. What do you want to achieve in terms of money? Let's just say a house. Assume that you will buy a house cash. Now use the minimum wage or an approximation to determine if you can afford one on your supposed salary in 10 years. Chances are you can't. Am I right? Then your supposed salary isn't enough. Congratulations! You have just discovered income streams. To get money you need to minimise risk with respect to your portfolio. That is, your income should come from several sources. There are multiple ways to achieve this: Through investmentOwned BusinessHigh income salaryand othersWhen I was a teen I started with the business. Being an entrepreneur doesn't mean that you have to drop out from your studies, on the contrary. Businesses can fail anytime. When your business fail and it is your only source of income, you are stuck and it's not nice. This is why I always recommend teenagers, who launch business to get a degree. A degree is a passport for a higher salary than the minimum wage and you can use your savings as investment in your business.A business is a side hobby first until it is profitable enough and this generally takes a minnimum of 2 years.Investing on stocks will yield a very small amount of dividents (if any) and you will achieve a passive income in several years. (picture credit: Kaboompics) If you are a teen these things are important. Educate yourself finantially; finantial illeteracy is the reason many academically educated people stay in dept.Learn about how to prevent a company from failingLearn about how to maximise a higher return of investment.The best way to make money as a teen is to minimise all risk. You can launch a sandwitch business and it has a failure rate of 50% (50% success, 50% failure) Add a juice as second income stream and suddenly your food business has a risk of 25%. (0.5*0.5=0.25 which is 25%) If you are launching a business, bootstraping is always less risky than taking a loan (which I do not recommend; you can't take a loan when you don't even know where and when the money will come from right?). Another alternative are incubators. Therefore the best way to make money as a teen is to minimise all risks; start by one income stream first then diversify. You will definetly find something suitable for you as a start. ~Danel 🎨🦋

Making money when you’re a teenager and feel like you can’t get a “real” job may require a bit of creative thinking… here’s just a few off the top of my head. 1. Offer to digitize people’s paper photographs. My 60 year old friends don’t have time to scan and save their photos, but they have the money to pay you to do it! (I think this is the best way for teenagers to make money, which is why it’s number one). 2, Find ways to turn your hobby into a money making business (making cupcakes, making rubber stamps, creating tiles, taming lizards, and making natural organic soap are examples of hobbies that can make teens money) 3. Experiment with lemonade or homemade cookie stands (when I was a teen, I made $52 in three hours selling raspberry iced tea on a busy neighborhood street) 4. Sell jewelry! Princess Jones says, “My mom would actually bring a shoebox full of my jewelry to her office and sell to her coworkers for me.” 5. Work at a carnival or traveling fair. I did this when I was 13 years old; I traveled with the Bill Dillard Exhibition for a whole summer! I didn’t make a lot of money, but had a fantastic time 6. Mow lawns and do yardwork 7. Do extra chores around your house 8. Walk dogs 9. Get a paper route 10. Get paid to do surveys at home (this is an investment – sometimes teens have to spend money to make money) 11. Clean people’s cars or garages 12. Ask your parents for a raise in allowance in exchange for extra chores

Way too open ended of a question for me to possibly give a rock solid answer. Depends on what age teen, if you are above your states legal working age you can try to get a part time job. What you can also do is sit down, and think about your skillset. What things are you Great at, which are you Good at, then what your average and terrible at. Be honest with yourself, and then you can try and figure out how to make money off of your best skills. For example, as a teenager I had zero interest in mowing lawns or any sort of landscaping, working at a fast food joint or any of that. It wasn’t that I was lazy I just sucked at those things. However I’ve been messing with computers in some form since I was 3 years old (Old Radio Shack Comadore like system). By the time I was a teenager, I could build systems from scratch and repair pretty much any pre-built on the market. Between my neighborhood, school and card shop connections while not a reliable and steady source of money, I got little jobs quite often (usually simple virus and malware cleanup). My main hustle though, every Friday of every season but winter mom would let me be an hour or two late for school and took me to whatever church or business parking lot was holding a carnival/festival/picnic and I’d go booth to booth as they set up to open that afternoon until one of the owners would hire me to work it for the weekend. It was a blast, they went on literally every weekend somewhere in the city and it paid just a little over minimum wage, but paid out nightly in cash. Other than that, I’d make magic decks for cheap, but that out performed their price point and sold them for a small profit and stuff like that. I wasn’t making great money by any means, but still on par with what I would have got working a little part time McDonalds gig, only I was having fun with what I did, and would have been miserable doing the fast food thing.

As a teenager (currently 21y/o), I made money in a few ways... 1.Mow lawns. It's that simple -- I mowed a ton of lawns, and brought in a few hundred dollars a week in 8th grade and beyond. My former employer actually sold a landscaping business when he was 18 for 250k back in the early 90s. 2. Invest in the stock market.  Before I get into this, I DON'T recommend this as a short-term moneymaking play. As a teen, you probably don't have a ton of cash. In my opinion, it's better to invest what little you do have in yourself during your formational years rather than putting money in the market unless you plan on pursuing a career in finance, in which you'll be able to simultaneously earn a real-world education.  But, if you choose to part ways with some money and have a good strategy / risk tolerance, you can make a decent return if you play your cards right. When I used to invest, I was a gunslinger. I traded stocks and 'bet the ranch' on volatile stocks back in '08 when I was 13 (aka the financial crisis / recession). I'm pretty sure I lost a lot of money back then. Who knows, but I was able to trade on volatility without really understanding much about stocks (not that that would've helped a ton anyways...everything went up and down in '08 for no reason at all)  3. Start a business. Anything. Just start it. Preferably a service business (avoid negative cash flow at all means) but start something. Do NOT worry about scaling. That will come later, if at all. I made both of the aforementioned mistakes. I tried scaling my profitable clothing company by leveraging a small credit line and was trying to compete with the big boys when I was 16. It ended up crippling the business that otherwise was relatively successful.  Note: this is just what I did. There are plenty of other ways, and while most people will say 'get a job' or 'do (insert menial task) for quick money', I'd like to think there are other ways as well. Think about. You're a teen. You may lack experience, confidence and so forth, but you understand why and how kids your age do things <-- that's important. Companies spend billions trying to figure it out. Figure out a way to make some money off of this. I did, or tried, and continue to try. Also, optimize for learning and doing rather than just making a few quick bucks. Learn some skills, like sales or how to code, even if it's just basic stuff. Find something you're interested in and double-down. Forget your weaknesses and what you don't like doing, this isn't school where you're taught to practice what you're not naturally good at. Hone your skills and use it as leverage. Outsource what you're not good at. This will lead to more interesting opportunities and ways to make money. Don't limit yourself or think you need degrees or awards or need to be an 'expert' to start. Fellow Quoran Casey Allen  ran a few businesses in his late teens / early twenties from house painting to a college-focused marketing agency. He has a ton of great insights on this topic as well. I actually interviewed him a few months which you can read here: http://www.howistartedmybusiness.co/casey-allen-entrepreneur-angel-investor/

Thanks for the A2A. My mother used to pay me for good grades. We were poor growing up, so it’s not like she had extra money. But it was very important to her that I get a great education rather than spend time working for below minimum wage. I am not saying this is right for you, and there is certainly nothing wrong with honest hard work to make money. But also consider the opportunity cost of your time. As a teenager, you are at a stage where learning has a lot of leverage - it can impact the college you can get accepted to, the career you will pursue, and many other things (including just the joy of learning!) So if you have to work to make ends meet, by all means, but if you can, I would learn rather than earn as a teenager. As for what to learn, the choices are many, and depend on you. I will point you to the area in which I have expertise in case it is one that interests you. I have put together a value investing reading course on my site that I have used to mentor aspiring value investors that I have worked with, if you are interested I think it is a good place to start. It picks the books that I have found helpful in mentoring people who are trying to become better investors, in an order that I think aids their development. As you read any investment book, I think it’s important to ask yourself if/how you would like to change your investing philosophy/process as a function of what you have read. The idea is not just to imitate well-known successful investors, but rather to understand why they did what they did, understand how their strengths/weaknesses compare to yours, and then try to see if there is anything you can take from your analysis to improve your own process.

I made money doing errands for people such as going to the store for them and delivering their stuff back home, going to the post office for them to send out or retrieve mail, etc. Cutting grass and cleaning house for neighbors is always an option, as is pet grooming, pet sitting and dog walking. If you like children and are of a responsible mindset, you could always offer to babysit as well. My cousin earned money growing up by doing computer maintenance for neighbors-getting rid of viruses and uneeded files, organizing videos and photos, cleaning up desktop and installing new programs, printers, and compatible gadgets. You could offer a laundry service to the elderly, to blue collar men who work long shifts and have limited time to devote to responsibilities, to stay at home moms who just have too much on their plate and even to college students who are crammed for time between work and studies or may not have easy access to a laundering facility. I've seen people charge $2-$4 per pound of clothing washed and dried, with folding included and ironing & being hung on racks just after laundering for transport costing extra. You can clean pools in the summer, clean doorsteps, porches, sidewalks and driveways of snow in the winter. You can clean leaves and bird nests from rain gutters and you can pull weeds from gardens and flower beds. The possibilities are rather endless when you are a teen. If its something a busy adult needs done but may not have the time or the physical ability to do, you very well could monetize your efforts to do it for them. The best way to decide which odd jobs you should choose is to step back and look at your neighbors as a whole. What kind of problem do several of your neighbors have that needs solved? Do many of them have trees nearby and could use a good lawn raking? Do several of them live on hills that are difficult to get up and down in the winter where they might appreciate someone offering to go to the store for them? Is your neighborhood of the fairly upscale kind where the people living there might travel often for work or maybe they take long vacations and cruises? If they have pets who need cared for during these times then they might find value in having you look after their pets while they are gone as opposed to placing them in a kennel. If you live in an area where several single moms have jobs, you could offer to retrieve their kids from the bus and keep them safely at your home and help with homework until they get home from work (provided your parents wouldnt mind, of course, and your bus arrives home before theirs does). They would certainly appreciate the homework aspect, given as how the moms would be tired after a long day and would still need to cook dinner, feed and bathe the kids plus whatever other things need done around the house. Simply getting the homework out of the way for them could be a huge help. That being said, you may even offer private tutoring in a subject you are good at to kids in grades below you. As I said, find a problem several adults have in the area. Solve it. Why several adults? Stability. Job security. If you do satisfactory work for one neighbor, they will instantly think to promote you to the next neighbor who talks about having that same problem. Word of mouth is great marketing and you want several mouths speaking about you and your skills. If a trusted friend tells me “so and so" fixed the problem for them, I'm calling “so and so", too, because my friend has already built my trust in them. Get a few friends hiring you where you will have gigs scheduled regularly or back to back, perhaps 3 or 4 times a week, depending on how much of your own time you have to devote to making money, and you should be able to save up for whatever it is you're wanting the money for in no time. Good luck with your entrepreneurial endeavors!

When I was 14 and 15 years old, I had a lawn mowing and weed trimming business in the summers. In the fall, I would rake leaves and load/unload hay bales on local farms. In winter, I would shovel snow and run errands for people in the neighborhood. Once I turned 16 and got my drivers license, I started working part-time at a local bakery. I would go in early and make doughnuts, then come back after school and clean the floors and wash pans. I also worked part time at Walmart a few nights a week as a stocker. I also took occasional jobs painting people’s porches, eaves, gutters, and wood fences. Now I teach high school. Some of my students make and sell cupcakes and breakfast burritos to earn pocket money and help save for college. One of my students has his own business called the Super Trooper Pooper Scooper. He picks up pet waste from people’s yards. When my oldest son was a teenager, he got a job at Best Buy selling phones. My younger son got a job at Movie Tavern as a server, and he eventually became the expo in the kitchen there (he supervised the kitchen staff and made sure all the orders were correct before sending them out to customers).

There are many easy and legal ways to earn money online. The question is how much money do you want to make online. The definition varies from one to another. #1 Take Surveys Online You can try to make money by taking survey online. However, it is not possible to make a living by filling up surveys and you will not be able to make a sustainable income. However, it is the simplest and the most straightforward way to make money online as it does not require any special skills and qualification. Below you can find a list of legitimate paid survey sites you can sign up. Pinecone ResearchPaidViewPointOpinion OutpostSwagbucksiPollVivaticGlobal Test MarketMySurveyiPanelIpsosHowever, there are pros and cons making money through paid survey sites. Pros:Easy and straightforwardYou do not need any special qualificationFree and you do not need to have special toolsYou can participate and take surveys anywhere you wantAll you need is a laptop/ smartphone and internet connectionCons:Small rewards from taking surveys. It is possible to make $5 per month if you work extremely hardEasily get screened out in the middle of the surveyLose all rewards after expiration durationIt does not allow you to make a sustainable income. You need to constantly participate in taking surveys every day.#3 Freelancing Freelancer.com is the most popular portal which allows you to bid on projects, there are lots of projects in freelancer. But as high as the projects, there are lots of bidders also which makes freelancer a tough platform to survive, but once you get good reviews its very easy to get projects. Apart from freelancer, there are other websites where you can do freelancing like Odesk, Elance, Project4Hire, GetaCoder, and ThemeForest. #2 Affiliate Marketing Alternatively, you can become an affiliate marketer. I graduated as an engineer and after years of working 9-to-5, I got fed up with the routine work and decided to do something else that could earn me an opportunity to spend quality time with my family and make extra cash. I started as a blogger and expected to make some extra cash like anyone else. To my surprise, it turned out well where I made more money than what I could as an engineer. My preferred way is to become an affiliate marketer because it allows me to make a lucrative and sustainable income through blogging. You can easily make $300 - $500 per day by becoming an affiliate marketer. To make money from blogging (affiliate marketing), First, you need to find your niche. A niche means a target or a subject that you are going to write about. A niche can be your interest, a hobby or a skill. Any subject can be your niche, for example, people blog about collecting match boxes, bug photography, work-out program, or even daily political scandals and etc. Remember one thing is when you are finding your niche, avoid being too broad with your selection. For example, do not blog about Work Out Tips and Motorbike at the same time. Both of them fall on different categories and they just can't simply be put together. You could do a post about your niche (e.g. camera, guitar, trekking) and include affiliate links to any paid ones (e.g. Amazon or ShareASale). Create great content is not enough to make a lucrative income online today. You will have to make use of social media platform to promote your content and drive traffic to purchase items via your product reviews. My site earned my $7,000 within six months. Of course, I worked extremely hard at the beginning and success did not happen overnight. I spent almost 5 hours per day after work to make it worked. As my site matures, I spend 1 to 2 hours every day writing, optimizing my site, connect to social media and reply readers' emails. The best thing is the earning potential doesn't stop there and the revenue growth is still climbing up every single day (provided I publish articles regularly). At the time of writing, my site is making 5-figure revenue every month. Anyway, my answer is if you're passionate about a subject and you have decent writing skills, blogging definitely could be an alternative career path for you to make a living. All you need is to become an affiliate marketer. You will also find the pros and cons working as an affiliate marketer. Pros:The earning potential is enormous due to the exponential growth of the internet usersIt allows you to make sustainable income onlineIt allows you to quit your nine-to-five job and allow you to spend quality time with your familiesIt is a legitimate online businessThere are many affiliate programs on the internet you can participate (e.g. Amazon, ShareASale, Apple, FreeflyVR)Cons:It requires a lot of effort and timeYou need to blog from time to time (constantly publish content)You need to learn how to do affiliate marketingYou can’t do it alone. It requires mentor-ship. You can do it alone with trial and error method but it takes a while to figure out the methodologyEasy to get scammed as a newbie as there are many so called internet Guru out there to steals your money and only deliver empty promises.I agree it is not easy to stand out on the market as there are millions of bloggers out there. However, it is still possible for a newbie to make a sustainable income online by choosing the right niche. Further reading: How to Make Money Online Legally and Effectively as a Teen (Under 18) Alex Founder of ManagingYourFinance.Com

Lots of answers along the lines of get a significant Internet presence and monitarize that. So just get a million YouTube followers and get rich. Look at a lot of channels, not many have a million followers and not many of them and they got there by being good content or they got there because they were started by someone famous in the first place. Even if you can pull it off, it will take some time to be in a place where you can actually generate a positive cash flow let alone a decent hourly return for your efforts. My recommendation is look at activities that you can do that not a lot of people want to do. Mow lawns and wash windows. I did this a lot when I was a teenager and could easily get double minimum wage. Best part was I got the cash as soon as I finished, no waiting 2 weeks until pay day. In Canada that was seasonal so in winter I shoveled snow. Not as dependable but after a large snow fall I could make several times minimum wage and work 12 hour days through the weekend. I often would make more after a large snowfall as my burger flipping friends made in a month. Do yard work. Especially in the spring and fall you can make good money in this. During winter time look for places where they have dogs and when the snow melt starts offer to clean the yard. Not pleasent work but it will not kill you. Once you get a reputation and more work than you can handle, hire others to help. You can charge out at twice minimum wage and pay minimum wage. Nice profit.

You could also opt to use existing websites for making money. These include both active income and passive income methods. For example, you could sell some used items or invest in creating some digital designs that they can be sold on merchandise. Again, devote a sizable portion of your time to passive income so that you can slowly build up earnings that will arrive on autopilot without any extra added effort. Of course, a large portion of these sites does have their own respective apps. But these are certainly less involved in the gig economy, and more so in the longer-term projects that exist in the fields of photography, online marketing, graphic design, and web development, for example. Craigslist: This site has been the go-to resource for over a decade now for people that are looking to make a bit of extra money online. You can easily sell your used stuff, rent out a spare room in your home or apartment, and offer up your services to the world. Upwork: This website offers a great marketplace for selling just about any professional service. You don't need a merchant account, the website of your own or anything else for that matter. All you need to do is be able to provide a high-quality service at a reasonable price. But be informed, you will have to compete with many others that are constantly bidding on open jobs. Cafe Press: This website allows you to create digital designs that can then be sold on the platform. You'll earn a commission for everything that sells and you'll never have to deal with logistics like printing, warehousing and customer service. If you have some graphic design skills, then this is a great potential source for your web-based income. Fiverr: Israeli-based Fivver was started in 2010 by Shal Wininger and Micha Kaufman. You can offer gigs as low as $5 but also get paid much more for upgrades and add-ons. Mechanical Turk: Amazon's Mechanical Turk is a resource for doing human-intelligence tasks, or as the site commonly refers to them, HITs. You get paid a very small fee for any given HIT and you'll need a good deal of volume to make a substantial amount of money. But it is a resource you can use in your spare time to generate a small income online. Flippa: If you have a penchant for buying and selling, you could use Flippa, and its higher-end counterpart, Deal Flow Brokerage to buy and sell websites for a profit. You'll need to know what you're doing here, but you could easily make a sizable income by flipping income-generating websites for profit. Etsy: While Etsy's popularity has declined recently, it's still a great resource for selling handmade items online. No need for complex e-commerce sites or merchant accounts or any sort of automation. The company takes a commission of every sale and charges a small listing fee per item. But many still use Etsy as their primary source of income. The best part is that you can also sell digital products here such as poster designs. To know more visit this link Make money online. I hope it will help you to find out more details information about online business.

What are the best ways to make money as a teenager? First, I’m going to assume three things: Teenagers are young, and thus can’t get a “traditional” job do to legal restrictions.Teenagers have little to no money, so any type of investment is out of the picture (no stock options, real estate, or even savings account interest).Teenagers have ample time.So, you can’t get a normal job, you have no money, but you have a lot of time? What can you do to make money? Summertime? Mow lawns! Of course this does require an upfront investment of owing a lawn mower and the gas to fuel it, but if you entrepreneurial enough, you can borrow someone’s, such as your parents, or someone else’s, perhaps in return for mowing their lawn.  Wintertime? Shovel snow from driveways! Again, you need something upfront… A snow shovel. Snow shovels tend to be cheaper than lawn mowers, though.  School time? Tutor! Especially if you’re really good in a particular subject, you could find someone who isn’t, and be compensated for helping them.  And of course, there’s the classic teenager job: babysitting! Get paid to watch someone’s children. In fact, you could even get paid to watch someone your own age if that person has some sort of disability or condition that prevents them from taking full care of themselves. P.S. I also wrote about 5 Ways to Make Extra Cash with No Upfront Investment, but while a teenager could potentially do some of the items in that article (they’re all online stuff) you might need to do it underneath a parent’s account. Unless you’re 18 or 19, which is technically a teenager but also a legal adult in most jurisdictions.

I think being a teen can be a great advantage as most neighbors are willing to not just pay for odd jobs but maybe teach you a trick or two depending on the job. With that being said, use all the resources available to you whether that be going around your neighborhood asking if there is any work that you can help with to looking at job posts. If you are a teen, I would say make sure to be wary of fake job posts, scams and other possible dangers. I think another really good way is to use your network, even your parents. Find what interests you or something that you think is going to be useful to you and ask if your parents know anyone that you can help and earn some money. Even for free, if you shadow someone long enough, you will learn the lessons and be able to ask for pay to help out at a later time. If I could go back to my teen, I would ask my friends dad, a contractor if I can shadow him to learn how to put drywall up, mud tape the walls, paint, frame and plumbing. These are not only fun (I think) but also very useful when you get your own house. I am not a lawyer so in regards to the legal sense of things I can't say what the labor law is for under 18. Also I am speaking in the context of North America.

Landscaping. I cannot stress this enough. Landscaping is the way to go if you want to make money as a teenager, for multiple reasons: 1.Who actually likes weeding? I’ll tell you one thing: my neighbors don’t. Adults have jobs they have to go to, children and husbands to attend to, rental properties to manage, medical injuries they have to nurse, and a whole host of other real-world conflicts that put yard work way down low on the priority list. Unless they have a zealous enthusiasm for weeding, most people would rather just hire someone to get the job done so they don’t have to worry about it. 2. You can earn higher than minimum wage by undercutting your competitors. It costs a lot of money to hire an actual landscaper. According to a google search I just found, it can cost someone anywhere between 45–75 dollars an hour to hire a professional service. As a teenager, you can charge $15/hr and make more than minimum wage (which is 11-something/hr in my area) while also guaranteeing that your business will look waayyy better to clients because you charge so much less than a landscaping company. Even though it will likely take you longer to do the work, it will still end up costing your clients less in the long run. Plus, people like to help out local teens- it gives them a feeling of goodwill and a sense that they’re being of service. 3. It doesn’t cost you much to get started. You probably have some weed diggers and shovels laying around the house. If not, you can buy used ones off Craigslist. If you’re going all out and getting a variety of tools, I still bet it’ll cost less than $50 to get everything you need. 4. You can strengthen your knowledge of gardening. Laying a tarp on the ground makes it easy to move a growing pile of weeds to your next weeding location. When trimming bushes, always start with the lower branches. A good way to weed a muddy area is to drag a hoe through the surface soil and scrape the weeds out. The best way to get rid of bindweed is to use poison; otherwise, it’ll just keep coming back. That weed-looking thing with the zucchini leaves is actually hollyhock, and it’ll put out beautiful pink flowers in the summer. These are all tips I’ve learned from people who have hired me to garden. When I go to my next job, I can teach what I’ve learned to future clients and utilize these techniques and knowledge to improve my work. 5. You make valuable connections and get free stuff. People often have me dig out plants they don’t want anymore. I take them home and plant them in my own garden. My clients all have different jobs; one is a project manager, another is a real estate agent, another is retired but has a penchant for knitting. One couple has dogs who need petsitting occasionally. The more people I know, the more opportunities open up to learn more about a different field or secure a different job opportunity in the future. I’ve made friends who give me handmade scarves and homemade cookies and anti-anxiety herbal tinctures for my dog. Through this, I’ve enriched my sense of community. It’s pretty awesome. 6. You set your own work hours. I make my schedule. I don’t have to answer to an irate boss, or wake up any earlier than I want to. Everything is on my own time. Downsides: Weeding is boring. You’ll want to invest in some music or talk radio or something.It’s hot outside. Work hours are limited to mornings and evenings and weather fluctuations.You get covered in dirt. This doesn’t bother me, but it might bother someone else.It takes muscle. I suck at using a shovel.Customers with unrealistic expectations. No, I do not have a bulldozer. Yes, it will take me more than an hour to weed your entire lawn. Sorry.All in all though, I highly recommend this job!

There is no easy way to earn money as a teen or at any other stage of life. Everything you do involves work. The thing is you have to find work you enjoy doing and what is enjoyable to you may not be enjoyable to someone else. So take a look at things you enjoy doing so far and what types of effort feel natural to you. Also think about things that take a lot of effort but you still enjoy the challenges. Finally, think about things that seem to test your endurance and turn you into a clockwatcher. These will give you clues on what you should look into and what you may want to avoid. Now, it must be said that experience is a good teacher, as well. You may be gung-ho on something till you actually start work doing it and decide that it isn’t for you. Youth is a nice time to try a lot of different things to get to know yourself. A favorite saying I once read is this: If you want a snake to learn its shape, put it in a box. It means by experiencing the confines of the box, a young snake learns what it is. Here are a few suggestions: If you like small children you might be happy starting and running a small babysitting/childcare business or work for an established one. You will need to keep the kids busy doing fun things and take good care of them and any infants in your charge. You will need to take a first aid babysitter’s course. If playing with small children is not your thing, do everyone a favor and skip this one. If you love horses, you might want to work at a horse ranch. If you love animals in general, you may want to get a job at an animal adoption center, humane society, animal hospital, or zoo. You may be able to get some valuable on-the-job training, references, and certifications if you are willing to volunteer first. If you love tractors, machinery and the outdoors, a being employed at a farm may be your best bet. If you have a strong interest in something and are willing to learn tech skills and purchase the right equipment, you might want to start a video channel and upload videos. If you love books and all things books, libraries and book stores may be for you. If you love clothes & accessories you may love working at a boutique or a department store so you can take advantage of their discounts. If you are good at a school subject, you might enjoy picking up some extra books tutoring other students. If you like to clean and organize, you might want to offer your services to neighbors and to the community. If you are quick and not easily rattled, fast food work could seem easy. The rate of pay for such work is slowly improving, and many places now offer tuition assistance for college. Sometimes family dining restaurants are in need of a weekend hostess who is personable so you might find that an easy gig. If you need some help finding a job, you should check out your state’s employment agency. They often offer some skills training and assistance to prepare you for interviews. They usually offer a jobs website where you can apply for jobs.

I'm an 18 year-old Law school dropout (still in school, different course) who's a company's social media manager and currently working on a startup (alongside a 45 year-old cofounder) that should launch in 4–6 weeks from now so I believe I am in a position to answer your question. To begin with, learn a skill. I started writing since I was six and started getting paid for it in 2014. I started the African Poetry Project and we made quite a couple of bucks from it. So first, learn a skill and being a (prospective) entrepreneur, either learn (digital) marketing, designing, accounting or coding - they'll pay off in the long run. And no, I'm not talking about school alone. Don't be shy to ask for payment for what you do. I've worked on Fiverr and the first time I got paid ($4 net) it was nothing but pure joy. So offer your services (after learning) on all e-platforms as well as physical businesses if you know an . The purpose of this is to earn you some bucks as well as give you a chance to learn on the job. Most important - CREATE! Your head is currently bubbling with lots of ideas (I guess). Pick out the one that wouldn't cost you a lot to start and just start.

So if you have an excellent social media following, then this may very well be the website for you. # 4 – Fiverr  This is not necessarily an affiliate website, although they do have affiliate offers. However, what makes this site such a great website is that you can promote YOUR skills. If you are an affiliate, you will be surprised how your skills can be valued on this website. Becoming an associate of theirs is relatively easy. Making a sell however can be a bit more challenging. However, if you are an affiliate and you have an offer then it should be a bit easier to make a sell. Know this — if you fail to make a sell in the first 90 days, they will terminate your account. You will be able to sign up two more times, but if you fail to make a sell, then you will not be able to use their service for some time.

Hi Andrew, You asked, What are the best ways to make money as a teenager? I recommend becoming a waiter or a waitress for the following reasons… Money is good: Though the salary is minimum wage, you earn a lot in tips. Flexibility is good: There are lots of different work shifts, so it’s easy to juggle college with being a waiter. It’s good because you get to meet a lot of different customers: Some will be nice, some will be jerks - it is valuable training to learn to deal with all kinds of people. Plus you can become the favorite waiter or waitress of some customers, and they can ask to be seated at one of your tables. It’s good because you will have to work with different managers: In one Red Lobster restaurant, there could be as many as 5 or 6 managers. Each with their own styles and standards. It is valuable training for your future to learn to deal with different managers. You will learn the ins and outs of business: You will learn how restaurant staff and menus are managed; what’s important to customer service, and more. Free or discounted food: You can usually buy food from the restaurant you wait at, at a discount. Backstory: My daughter was a part time waitress at a Red Lobster, in her freshman and sophomore years of college. She was able to juggle work and college, even though she was in a 4 year college and her major was in engineering. With the money she was making, she regretted not having started waitressing when she was in high school itself. This advice comes from seeing how good a job it was for her, and seeing her W2s at tax time every year.

What skills do you have? Skills are things like programming or yard work or cooking or cleaning. What transportation so you have? Are you on foot, bicycle or motor vehicle. What range can you work in. What are you willing to do? I know how to clean toilets, I do not want to do that particularly. If you have inventoried your assets now for the fun part. Look at you skills in the broadest terms possible. Are you willing to mow lawns or clean houses? Are you willing to help someone who is elderly? Can you write code? Do you want to design web pages? Can you run errands for people or walk dogs or wash dogs (and cats). Are you able to groom animals? Are you willing to hand wash cars? Are you good at making things like cool keyrings or paracord jewelry? Are you good at getting people to make these for you? Do you enjoy music. Can you record workout music sets or dance music? Are you good at garage sale shopping? Buy stuff to resale or help setup and run garage sales. Most people have too much stuff. Are you good at organizing? Help clean out garages. You are young to be working in the US at a company. Working for cash. You have all sorts of options. Are you good with a camera? Take personal pictures or pet pictures or pictures for stuff people want to sell online. Selling online, there are all sorts of options. Personal services. Running errands. Selling stuff. The details. Whatever you do, you need your parents approval and support. Be on time or early. Do a great job. Set a price BEFORE you do any work. If it is complicated, write it down as a check list and proof you did everything they asked. Be willing to ask to be paid. If things get odd or the customer wants you to do more than you agreed to do. Reach out to your parents and get out. Some people are jerks. Go on to the next job. Best of luck.

After 3 months of kicking ass on these guys social media campaigns you should have A) some metrics that prove you are good at social.B) metrics that prove that social helped these businesses. C) 3-5 references and testimonials.  Then I would turn around and ask the people who's campaigns I had been running if they would like to upgrade to a retainer fee in order for me o continue my services, and also ask them to give me the names of 3 other business people they know, who's biz could be improved by social media help.  There you go. That's the beginning of a social media agency. If you continue to target small to medium business' and market yourself as an expert on Gen i/y you could build a steady business that requires very little capital to get started.

College life isn’t cheap. And so, it would certainly help if you could bring in a little bit of extra money, right? Fortunately, today that’s a lot easier to do than it used to be, as the online working space has created a huge opportunity for students to make that extra bit of cash that will help them move from surviving into living. Now, we all know about the more common places to make money online. You can play poker, write for magazines, or perhaps use one of the big online freelancing platforms, for example. Still, there have to be better ways than that to make money, right? That’s right. There are new opportunities constantly cropping up. Let’s discuss a few of them here. Virtual assistant Are you a bit of a jack of all trades and do you frequently like to change things up? Then consider becoming a virtual assistant. Virtual assistants do a lot of stuff. For example, they might send out emails, write out dictated texts, set meetings, or arrange travel itineraries. Work on Fiverr - Freelance Services Marketplace for The Lean Entrepreneur The key to Fiverr - Freelance Services Marketplace for The Lean Entrepreneur is what is called the ‘micro gig’. These are small tasks that don’t make you that much money, but because they don’t cost you a lot of time, it can still really add up. What’s more, as many of these jobs aren’t that difficult, there is a real paternity to get started in te gig economy here. Sell stock photos Are you good with a camera? Then why not try to sell some stock photos? The big stock photo websites are always looking for new content that they can put up on their sites. Then you’ll get a royalty every time somebody buys that picture. Work for an essay writing service If you’re further along in your education and you’ve got a natural knack for writing academic essays, then why not join an essay writing service? They’re all over the internet and they can be great money makers if you know what you’re doing and how to put together a reference table. Sell your artistic creation on Shop for anything from creative people everywhere If academics is not where it’s at for you and you’re a more creative type, then consider turning to etsy.com instead. This is a marketplace for the creatively and alternatively minded and is a wonderful place for you to sell your most artistic creations. Affiliate marketing Have you been writing a blog for a while and have you got a decent following? Then why not consider affiliate marketing? This is where you list products on your site and if people follow the link and buy the product, you get a little bit of money for that. Teach students in less advantaged countries There are a lot of universities out there that probably aren’t as good as yours. The teachers might not be as good and the education standards might not be so high. The result? A lot of students in less-developed countries are looking for guidance and information from some of the better universities to get that edge that they otherwise wouldn’t have. Sell tickets online As a student, you can often get tickets for events way before the public does. So why not turn that into a small business? Of course, you’ll want to stay below the radar, but if you do it cleverly and know who is interested in these kinds of things, it’s easy money. Do some online surveys There are plenty of websites out there that will pay you to do surveys. For example, Pinecone will pay you for doing surveys. You can also use the points you collect to get prizes. Last words And really, that’s just the tip of the iceberg. There are plenty of other things that you can do out there. Just do a search with whatever you’re good at with the words ‘make money’ and plenty of results should pop up. Teenage is the time when you roam around freely without caring for the world. Life is not easy for everyone, and some teens might think of earning money at this stage. If you’re one of them, it’s a perfect choice. There are many benefits of starting to earn from an early stage. First of all, you are prepared enough to face the world. When you grow up and go for job interviews, you can highlight this stage of your life. Your employers would be impressed by your willingness to work at such a young age. Now, let’s come to the central part. How do you make money as a teenager? Here are some of the best options. Start with simple tasks.You can babysit, mow lawns, wash cars, or take pets for walks. Starting with simple tasks will allow you to develop a working habit. You can gradually progress to more complicated tasks. •	Rope in your friends. Working in groups is the best way to start if you are a teenager. Consider common interests and start a small business. You can make dresses, jewelry, or even create your own event management company. The options are endless. Apart from that, you can also ask your parents to guide you. Remember, you don’t have to earn the world at this stage. Start small, and you will soon make it big. Hope I've answered your query well!

If you want to do work with Photoshop, etc, you would need to market yourself. The fact that you can speak several languages is helpful. If you write well, you can look for freelance writing opportunities. I would sign up on websites that provide such opportunities and see if you can get some jobs. This will let you build a portfolio, perhaps get some referrals from happy clients and so on. Go to some local businesses and ask them if they are interested in having you make new signs or whatever for them. Perhaps they would be interested. In other words, hit the streets. Make sure to stay in safe areas though and let your folks know what you are doing. Maybe you could get some work doing translation. Companies that would like their websites or documents translated. Honestly, I don't know whether anyone will hire you.  There are limitations to being 14 and trying to get jobs. All sorts of legal issues can come up, including the fact that you cannot sign a contract at your age. But give it the old before-college try.  You can also do some more traditional work that is common for  young folks, such as mowing lawns, shoveling snow, raking leaves. If you don't mind physical labor, go to your neighbors and ask if they would like some help.  If you have the ability to sell antiques, and the cash to fund purchases, you could always do some buying at estate sales and reselling at your step-father's booth. There are always estate sales on the weekends.

First off there are no easy ways to make money for anybody. As a teenager you likely have some advantages over someone older. You may have low expenses as your parents may be covering basic survival needs—food, clothing, transportation, and medical expenses. You don’t have anyone besides yourself to provide for. You are young and more energetic than someone older. You can start at the very bottom because you have no one you need to impress. Starting at the bottom means you can work your way upward. You may have school but still have a great deal of free time available. Things you should consider: Do the dirty jobs—cleaning up dog poop out of neighborhood yards, cleaning animal cages at vet clinics, washing cars and pressure-washing houses and fences, lawn care and landscaping;Do the jobs that may not pay so well now but offer great learning experiences—assistant or apprentice to auto mechanic, plumber, construction runner, office runner [check law firms for these].Jobs you take on as a teenager may lead you to a lucrative career later on but they don’t have to. Maybe you want a job where you can have fun—work in a movie theatre or theme park—or get free or reduced meals as part of your compensation. Some companies offer tuition assistance or reimbursement for college. Remember you are trading your time for money and other perks. Don’t waste it trying to live a lifestyle to impress other people. Many of the people you know now will be strangers to you in 20 years. They will neither remember nor care about the impressions you made way back when. Your employers, though, do remember the extraordinary efforts made by someone in their first job and can serve you well as character references in your future.

First understand that everything in life is about making decisions, setting priorities and taking action. It is much easier to get a lot something than a little bit of everything. The best skills you can learn at a young age are the discipline to do what others will not and salesmanship. Being able to sell your self will put you head and shoulder above most adults that you will encounter throughout your life.  I would suggest an old school sales job. Start small and grow a business. My daughter had a friend who would go to Costco and buy canned sodas and snacks to sell at school. The school vending machines were very expensive so she could beat the school price and still make a profit.  How much money did she make? Selling just sodas and snack she was making about $100 per week. After a while she added some cheap merchandise like earbuds (kids always lose them) and even handmade purses. Don’t pick these products. You need to research your market and sell what your classmates want. Some weeks she would make $300. All at school and just a couple of hours at Costo each week.  That may not sound like much money, but she never had to work at McDonalds and was free to set her own schedule and have enough money to buy what she wanted. Remember that this is not just about having some extra money, but learning some skills that will benefit you for a lifetime. Best of luck!

The sooner you start investing, more you’ll have at retirement or you can retire early. My older daughter started investing nine years ago. She now has over $510,000 worth of stocks. She’s 33 years old, and she has cerebral palsy, spastic quadriplegia, and is non-verbal and can’t walk. This brings us to your first part of your question. Some smart ways for teens to make money. You’ll have to see what’s available in your area. I used to buck bails of hay, paint fences, built rock walls, re-roofed houses, and so on. That doesn’t do you much good if you live in a city. You’ll have to find a need and exploit it. Are there bike riders in your area? If so, maybe start off with patching tires and putting new chains on. From there, start carrying parts that are commonly needed. Maybe find abandoned bikes and rebuilt them to sell. Like I said, you’ll have to look for opportunities to exploit. When I needed money the most, I looked for and found old furniture that needed to be repaired. I made sure they weren’t cheap pieces. I repaired them, then sold them on Craigslist. Many cities have trash day when everyone can throw away their furniture and large household items. I once found a motorscooter that had a torn seat. Nothing else was wrong. It started right up! That one was pure profit. The city sometimes allow the item to sit for a week before coming around to pick them up. Search around then to find anything you think people would want if it was repaired and restored. Craigslist is a great place to search, especially their free section, to find things to resell on Ebay. A buddy of mine found an old hammer head along side the road on the way to my place. He put a handle on it, and sold it for more than what he paid for the handle but less than a new hammer. Once you get your mindset to find opportunities, creating opportunities will come easier. Best of luck to you!

How to make money as a teenager This might surprise you, but there are few ways to make money that adults can make but teenagers can’t. The most important lesson you can learn is that the way to make money is by serving others. You can make money by starting your own business such as mowing lawns or babysitting. You could start a paper out or flip burgers at a fast food restaurant. You could start a website by finding a niche to serve and a way to help people solve the problem. YouTube is really popular, you could start a YouTube channel. If you have a particular skill that you can exploit, you can make money on Fiverr or Upwork. With a little money to invest, you can find items for sale at thrift stores, on clearance, at yard sales, etc. and sell these items on eBay or Amazon. If you’re interested in making money in the long term, you could take time now to learn a skill such as programming or data analysis. These skills will pay out big after you’ve learned. These are just a few ways that you or anyone, regardless of your age, can earn a little bit of money. Figure out what works for you and take action.

Do you want a short list of Ideas or the actual details of how to go about earning money? I favour the latter : ) GARDEN WORK. Often people who are perfectly able but just don’t have time to maintain their garden would LOVE to have help from a willing teen who’s able to pull up weeds, mow the lawn, paint the fencing/shed with woodstain, maybe powerwash the outdoor seating or paint the garage door. If you’re good at Technical things you could teach people how to set up an Email Account or connect to the Internet, set up Online Gaming etc. Older people would enjoy being able to play Online Scrabble with their friends. You could show people how to set up a WEB CAM so they could enjoy video calls to overseas relatives. That’s good for their grandkids too. If you learned a skill like Face Painting, Balloon Twisting, you’d get invited to work at Birthday Parties etc. Nail Art, Dog Walking, fetching groceries or newspapers for Pensioners if they don’t get things delivered or they just want a few forgotten items, you’ll get calls from people offering you work. I’ve just asked for 2 teenage girls (age 14) to do some gardening. These are relatively easy ways to make money but if you had access to a greenhouse or a space in someone’s unused Veg Plot you could grow food & flowers, sell them at a Boot Sale. Whilst growing from seed is the cheapest route, it’s economic (and smarter) to buy trays of established Plug Plants and grow them outside or in the greenhouse to 6″ tall then sell them. NB. It’s Good Karma to offer some of your home grown flowers FREE to a local Church or Hospice to brighten up their Entry Hall or Reception. Some people may appreciate if you’d look after a Family Burial Plot. During Summer you could visit the Cemetery, strimmer around the grave and replace the flowers with fresh ones. You could be a Bike Courier cycling between Estate Agents & Solicitors delivering Documents within 1hr instead of them posting them. Work from Home - Build E-Bikes? If you have a Start-Up Fund of $300 you could buy a $100 bike, a $100 hub motor (sell the spare wheel for $20) $80 for a Li-on battery, assemble it into an EBike and sell it for $500. If you built & sold just 1 bike each day, starting with $300, by the end of the first 5 day week, you’d have $1300! After you’ve sold just 2 bikes, you have enough Funds to purchase the Parts for 2 more, so if you can build & sell 2 bikes a day, now you’re making $2000/week. I should really try this myself! PROOF READING Despite the existence of software like Grammarly, many errors get past spellcheckers etc. and Authors don’t like to send scripts/screenplays to Publishers with glaring errors. Grammarly won’t likely pick it up if you’ve skipped out a passage of text, or if you used a valid word incorrectly. If your Literacy is good, you could get casual work in this area. Uni/College Lecturers often give this type of work to Students so check Notice Boards. ChildMinding, Dog Walking, House Sitting, Banned Driver Chauffeur? If you have a Driving License you may be allowed to drive a neighbour to work if they’ve been banned for 3–6mths or if they have an injury which stops them driving. Even if you have to pay a Premium on your Insurance it may still be worth doing, eg. you might get charged an additional $5-10/wk but earn $30-40 from Driving, pay it. Don’t be tempted to do Takeaway Deliveries without having Commercial Driving Cover as you are effectively driving UNINSURED if you do. They want you to deliver quickly and that, combined with middle of the road stops, increases your risk of accidents. Whatever work you get, work Legally, and Safely.

To put on my “mom friend,” voice, particularly the stern variant of that voice, get a job. That’s by far the easiest way to make money as a teenager. Get a job. Even if you don’t have any work experience. There are all kinds of places that hire first-time workers. You’ll want the work experience, for one. Having a job as a teenager is a good way to avoid having zero work experience after you graduate high school. Plus, having a job is a good way to build skills — even if you wind up working at a McDonald’s. Not only will you learn how to work in a fast-paced restaurant environment, you’ll learn team-building and cooperative skills. Write yourself up a resume (if you don’t have work experience, put down things like the school activities you’ve participated in, the skills/languages you have, and the awards you’ve won), and go around to various locations in your neighbourhood to see if they’re hiring. You can also apply for jobs online, but I’ve found that you’re far more likely to get hired if you show up in person — that shows initiative. If you keep applying and make sure you’re decently well-dressed when you show up to inquire about jobs, eventually, you’ll get hired. Once you do get hired, work your butt off. Then, every two weeks, collect your paycheque. Voila. You now have money — not just a fixed amount of money, but a continuous source of income, as well as a way to gain contacts and work experience for future jobs. Look at you go.

Making money as a teenager will give you some added freedom - you’re no longer 100% reliant on your parents. Congratulations, you’ve started to grow up. Understanding money as a teenager is a whole different story. I’ve always loved cooking, and from 14 I’ve made my own packed lunch for school - not because my parents can’t cook, but because I prefer my own cooking (sorry mum!). I started to become reknowned for my wraps which I got up and cooked myself every morning. My friends starting asking for a taste, and I usually got positive feedback. My inner entrepreneur sensed an opportunity. It began just with a few friends - my girlfriend at the time, a close footballing pal of mine and a few others. Now I didn’t just wake up to make myself lunch, I also had others relying on me. Fast forward 6 months and I was making an average of 20 lunches per day. I won’t go into my exact finances, but let’s just say I was making on average of 500% profit margins. Fortunately, with no overhead (running out of my kitchen at home), I was pocketing most of the cash, and can now safely say from my year and a half operating, ‘wrap god’ (my name for my business - a pun on the Eminem song), I have saved enough to buy my first car, take a trip around the world, keep myself afloat through a hard 6 months I may encounter in my future, or even start something else. I worked alone, with little to no help from others. I did mostly my own promotion within school, and all my own shopping. So what do I mean by understand money? During my time in operation, I woke up at 5 every morning to cook before school, because it provided the best possible experience . Every penny I made was earned through physical work. I sacrificed 2 hours off every day to keep my little business running, and to keep my ‘customers’ satisfied. I may not have started a fancy internet business, or something that was necessarily scalable, but everything I earned represented value I was directly adding back to my community. Before, I could head into town with some pocket money in my hand and come back with nothing left, and feel nothing. Now, everything I spend means something to me. I truly understand what the phrase, ‘money hard earned’ means, and I no longer take anything I have for granted. My first question when there’s any mention of a family holiday, a new house accessory, or anything of the sort is financial. Don’t learn to make money - strive to understand it. Give it some meaning to you.

response.answer_text: Are you musical? Play an instrument, sing? Can you do something else that people would like to watch? Yes? Then busking. AKA street performing. No, it isn't just for people who desperately need the money. Busking is for anyone with a talent to share. Find a business, preferably somewhere slightly on the busier side. Ask the owner of that business if you can perform on their property, after explaining what you wish to do. If it's a small business that needs publicity, they're almost guaranteed to say yes! Get your act ready, whether it's playing an instrument, breakdancing, juggling, whatever. Wear something nice-ish, in case you see someone you know ;). Ready a container to collect tips in. You're doing this for profit, after all. If your act is playing an instrument, use your case. And then.. perform! Have fun! Earn some money! Don't be discouraged if you don't collect much right away. If you establish yourself as a performer near that business you chose, people will eventually expect to see you. You might even get some regular customers. A tip for earning more money: People like to feel like they're helping more people. They'll be more likely to pay you if they know that you're not just going to use the money for yourself. Pick a local charity and establish that you're going to donate a percentage of your earnings to them. Make a sign, and put it right up next to or on your money collecting container. If you have a sign that says 1/3 of all profits goes to charity, or something similar, people will feel like they're being a productive member of society by giving to you. It helps you, it helps the charity, it helps the business you're performing in front of. Everyone wins.

The best thing to do is to make money doing what you love. Since you love fencing, I suggest you working in the fencing industry. You can work as a fencing teacher, you can put out fencing videos online. You can make a blog about fencing. The money might not come straight away but since you are doing what you love, why not? If you do well, you will make a ton of money in the future.  If you need the cash fast, then you need to start a service which is teaching people how to fence. Hand out flyers around your neighbourhood saying that you are starting a beginners to fencing class and charge the first few lessons for free. Since your students would most likely be younger than you, ask their parents to watch you teach their kids. After a few free lessons, let the parents charge you what they want. FiverrWith Fiverr you can do small tasks and get paid $5 for it, hence the name "fiverr" on fiverr you'll find that many people sell graphic designs, voice overs, etc. However that stuff is saturated you need to be creative and sell something that stands out. Easiest way is your relatives. Have an aunt that works in HR but is clueless on using a computer? Offer to help and negotiate a price. Don’t be greedy, but don’t undercut yourself either. I had an aunt that I would help her with computer related stuff and I didn't charge much because It was guaranteed she’d be calling me to come back soon and she lived less than a mile from me. My grandmother hired me to cut her grass, patch a hole in the wall thanks to a cousin, mount her TV and I assembled her old TV cabinet. Another way is doing deliveries for Postmates on your bike. If you don’t already, get a good commuter bike, large backpack, and insulated food bags and you’re good to go. You won’t be able to deliver alcohol until you turn 21, but you can deliver food and run errands. Plus you can log on or off anytime you want. Grubhub pays better, but you have to be on a schedule. Enroll in a vocational/trade school. You can learn a lot of useful trades and be able to do more work for relatives. My first electrical job was installing a doorbell for an aunt. I was never certified, just knew enough to be dangerous. Since then I've replaced outlets and switches, installed and replaced ceiling fans, and repaired apartment intercoms that the tenants were willing to pay me for the work because building management was too slow. You can also try apprenticeship with a electrician or carpenter for example. For minimum wage or less you can be a helper and learn from a professional and once you get certified, you can work for them or start your own business. You can also take online courses or watch youtube instructional videos. Buy a clunky beat up car from a junkyard and try to get it running again. And now you are a mechanic and as time and money permits, you can build your own workshop in your parent’s garage. You can always donate blood or plasma for money. It’s not a lot, but it’s pocket change and tax free income. Sell stuff on ebay. Figure out what stuff you can sell. Go to flea markets or search on apps like OfferUp or LetGo for cheap stuff and then turn around and resell it. Buy some junky smartphones and try to repair them. Once you learn how, you can market yourself for doing phone repairs. Advertise at community colleges or high schools. Only work for cash. There are more ways but the point being that these are ways to make an honest buck as a teenager and can be turned into jobs when you reach adulthood. I have done most of these myself and shocked people how I could afford nice toys and gadgets when I didn’t have a job.

When you’re young, you can practice doing smaller task to make money that will eventually teach you the mentality and skills to pursue bigger businesses as you age. You’d be surprised how many items you have laying around that you haven’t touched in months. A lot of videos games can be sold for a good amount of change too!Ask your neighbors if you could mow their lawn or have a car wash in your local neighborhood. Example: You find an old laptop at a garage sale for $40 and sell it online for $200. Find something you are skilled at and go on Fiverr or Upwork and try to see if anyone would be willing to pay you to do what your offer. Whatever it is, there is someone out there who would be willing to pay you for it.Hope these tips helped. There are also apps that pay you money just for playing games. I found a video showing one app that pays you for playing. You can see the Youtube Video Here.

I have just stumbled across matched betting, there is a lot of stuff out there on this topic and unlike some of the other stuff like blogging (I have tried it) it has instant reward. Best of all its totally legal This answer is from my blog Personal Evolution where I go into more detail: We've all seen the adverts for Bookies offering stuff like: bet £5 and we'll give you £20 for free! These have been going on for years! The question has always been is there any way to get that £20 without risking it? Enter betting exchanges! These allow people to take a position on the opposite outcome. I'll explain with a... Quick Example: Manchester City vs Arsenal There are 3 outcomes for Manchester City... Win, Draw or Lose. At the bookie (i.e. Ladbrokes) you would "back" (bet for) an outcome (i.e. Manchester City to Win). However at an exchange you "lay" (bet against) the outcome (i.e Manchester City not to win - which means you bet for them to lose or draw). So that's the basic mechanic of the exchange.. Why does this mean free money? Now using both the Bookie and Exchange you can bet on all outcomes of the game i.e risk free This in its self is useless because you would still lose money if you did this with just your own money... However using the free bets we can effectively get money for nothing... Because by betting for and against the outcome of the match you can guarantee a slice of that free bet.

As a teen you can make money via retail arbitrage. Retail arbitrage is basically when you will go to a store like Walmart or Target and you go to the clearance aisle or if you see an item that's much cheaper than it usually is you can actually get that item and then you can check the price on places like eBay Amazon or Facebook marketplace. Then go ahead and sell it for more than what you paid. A lot of people do this with kids toys, and they buy them in bulk when they’re on sale. There'll be like big Lego sets like 80% off and people buy like 10 to 20 LEGO sets resell them on eBay or Amazon and make like $300 - $500 profit. There are people that actually do retail arbitrage as a full-time income I'm not saying you guys are gonna make a full-time income but it is a great way to make a couple 100 if not a couple extra thousand dollars every single month.
