As a teen, I did yardwork, bussed and waited tables in a couple of cafes, along with washing dishes, worked at a country club, and worked construction as I got bigger, and older. I did some farm work, too, picking watermelons, and baling hay. I worked a summer as an electrician's helper. If you think you're too good to do that sort of work, or that it's only fit for some other race, or illegal immigrants, you won't make money. Everybody on most of the jobs I worked had no problems with other citizens, but we all would have fought foreigners for our low-paying jobs. One of my brothers, and a friend of his stocked shelves at Kroger, but all stores need stockers. You can get certified as a lifeguard, and work at a municipal or country club swimming pool, or caddy at a golf course. If you get a job, do it right, without bitching about it. Prove yourself to the boss, and leave the phone in the car; you aren't being paid to play with it! I got promoted to better positions, by bosses who saw the potential in me, based by how I handled the tasks assigned to me. If you are picking up litter, pick it ALL up. Don't claim knowledge you don't have, but be trainable. Be the one who steps up to the task, instead of hoping someone else gets put on that one. The best jobs are the ones you get, and make money at, not the ones someone else has. Those are filled already. It doesn't hurt to apply, though.

Washing cars during hot months. Selling Christmas trees and firewood during December. Landscaping, cutting grass and planting flower beds during the Spring and Summer. Starting your own store selling drinks like Coke, Pepsi, Dr. Pepper, Sparkling Water, Powerade, Gatorade, Tea and Coffee. Selling ice cream, yogurt, candy, toiletries like shampoo, deodorant, soap, razors, toilet paper, etc. Working in a library, museum or at a newspaper, radio station or television station. Maybe working at a restaurant or bakery if you enjoy that. Men may enjoy house or apartment painting and remodeling. Working at a movie theater or concert hall selling tickets or snacks. Some churches hire teenagers. A lot of colleges do too. Working at a football or baseball stadium. Working for a pawnshop or bank. Try working for a doctor or lawyer's office.

Convince yourself that you are willing and able to do ANYTHING (legal). If you, at your young age, will do what other people do not want to do, you can make money at it. It will probably not be the start of a career, but it will give you a jumping off point to build on or expand upon. It may very well act as a guide to show you what you don’t want to do. I started at 17 years old as a maintenance assistant at a heavy equipment company. I learned some basic mechanical skills. but usually was kept busy cleaning the yard, doing a lot of sanding and spot painting and helping the older, more senior guys perform some more complicated task. Knowing I probably did not want to do this sort of work as a career prompted to apply myself at the community college I attended that fall. I discovered that I liked psychology and that I could write. I ended up leaving school with an Associates degree (A.A./Humanities). I worked in retail for a couple of years, when a good friend, who had a degree in Communications/Marketing from Penn State wrangled me an interview for a sales job at a small newspaper. I really liked it and left there 17 years later in middle management. With a couple of marketing and sales jobs in between, I ended up working for a state agency in Labor and Industry, a very dry technical job with great benefits. I retired after 6 years with a small but welcome pension. The moral of the story, be willing to try anything and give it your best shot. Act as if your life depended on the job you have, whatever it is. You can never tell where it will lead or what door it will open later in life.

Right now, it’s hard for teenagers to earn money because we…really can’t go anywhere, but when life starts back up, here are a few ways that teenagers can earn money: Ages 13–15 Mowing lawns. I don’t mow lawns for money since I don’t really like lawns, but if outdoors stuff is your thing, then mowing peoples’ lawns is a good way to make money, get exercise, and do something you enjoy.Kill random insects. No, seriously. Did you know that there are a lot of people who dislike carpenter bees? All you need is a tennis racket, just saying…Organize a bake sale. If you like baking and cooking, you could make a bunch of baked goods and sell them.Do other odds and ends. Usually someone will pay you for doing something they don’t want to do.Ages 16–19 In addition to the previously stated things, teens in this age category can usually: Get a job. You can probably get a decent minimum wage job at 16—go work at McDonald’s or Wendy’s. These usually are decent jobs for teenagers.Tinker around. At this age, you might be mechanically inclined or inclined toward other manual labor. You shouldn’t have too hard of a time getting work like that.Lifeguard. That’s what I’m planning to do. If you’re a good swimmer, then this could be a pretty good job.Babysit. You likely can drive, and you also likely have a phone, so this is a great way to make money if you like kids—or can fake liking kids.Tutor. I do this as well. I’m tutoring another person in Latin. If you’re a good enough student, this can also be a pretty easy way to make money.Overall, I’d say the biggest thing is motivation. Making money takes effort and time. You have to be committed in order to make money. Any of the above would be great for a teenager looking to make money. But you have to be willing to commit to it. If you aren’t, then I’m sorry, you aren’t ready to be making money. Civility. Honesty. Diversity. Andrew Steiner

If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Don't fall for the “get rich quick" schemes. “Just buy my book to find out how”. The only person getting rich is the one ripping you off. The book says you rip off other people. (It's called a pyramid scheme.)Very few people get rich from YouTube videos. Everybody between the ages of 11 and 18 wants to do this. It's an unrealistic expectation , unless you have something very unique.Get a job. Ask around, do odd jobs for people, or get weekend or evening work in a shop or restaurant.Buy stuff and sell it for a small mark up. Be very aware of counterfeit goods and research taxes if you want to import goods from abroad. Be aware of your legal obligations, and what to do if a customer has a problem or complaint.Learn to fix stuff (e.g. mobile phones) and offer a service doing this.Work hard. Really hard. Making good money involves a lot of effort and dedication . It won't just fall in your lap.

I’m not sure what you mean by “really easy”. But, I’ve got a few ideas of how you can make some money. Work a part-time job (cashier, waiter/waitress, pizza delivery, fast food line cook, etc. Probably the easiest, most realistic option for teenager)Do chores for other people (pet-sitting, pool cleaning, washing cars, babysitting, lawn mowing, math tutoring, leaf raking)Buy and resell stuff on Amazon, eBay, etc (you may need to pay monthly fees for both, however. Hard to make a sale, too due to competition)Launch a lemonade or cookie stand (you might need a license to handle food for that)Use a money-making app (ex: Uber, Lyft, or DoorDash if you’re old enough to drive and have a valid drivers license)Make art and sell your work at vintage markets and craft fairs (those can be a little expensive, though. And, you need to be good enough at art first).By the way, ignore anyone who talks about how easy it is money online. It’s very time-consuming and expensive to make money online. If you’re looking for an easy way to make quick money as you asked in your question, making money online ought to be way down the list of things you can do.

You can mow lawns and make a TON of money. As long as you have a mower, you can ask your neighbors if you could mow their lawn. If they say no, go to another house and ask them. If they say yes, agree on a day that you can mow it and a price. I can’t tell you how much to charge, as it all depends on the size of the lawn. Look up pricing info online and try to charge a bit less than a company would, as you are not a professional. Above all, do an excellent job on their lawn, ESPECIALLY on the first mow, as the first mow is like a first impression in meeting somebody important. Do a great job, and you will most likely be able to mow their lawn every 1 or 2 weeks. If you have the time and can manage it, add more yards to your route. With just 1 lawn, you should be making at least 20 dollars, and that is the BARE minimum. (Very small lawn.) It should only take you around an hour to mow a lawn if it is a medium to big lawn, depending on the mower. A small lawn can take as little as just 20 minutes to mow, while a very large lawn can take 2 hours or more, although you would get paid a lot more for that. The easiest lawns are not only the smallest, but the ones without any obstacles in your way. Yards with multiple trees or rock formations can be harder to mow, as well as downhill sections without room to turn around at the end, causing you to have to pull the lawn mower back up the hill, which can be very strenuous. It may feel like a lot of work, but you can easily make at least 100 dollars in just a couple of hours of mowing. When you’ve finished, you’ve got the money and still have almost all of the day to do whatever you want to do!

These days with the Internet I think making websites for new/small business is a great way for the teenagers to make good money, especially over the summer break if they live in the U.S. An hour a night after homework will have a new website up in a week or two. They all learn code from school, or their peers. They are all computer/gamers/social media orientated and there are new Mom and Pop or Facebook small businesses starting up every day. These often bootstrapped startups need reasonably priced promotional help. Many don't realize that there are companies on Facebook that only sell their products on Facebook. They could promote their abilities on the same site. My son helps me with research writing Sci-Fi novels, checks my website, and cleans my computer every time it is needed. I pay him for doing what I'm not good at.  It always shocks me how much the kids of today know about the modern world and its systems.

As teenager we find ourselves suddenly in need of extra allowance which our parents refuse. Part time work is a nice way to earn the extra cash, as well as to brighten up your CV in the future. Here are ways a teenager can earn money: 1.	Sell your artworks. If you are good at painting or handicrafts, then look up as to how you can take your hobby a step higher and make artworks that are of a more professional level. Depending on your quality of work and audience market you can earn a lot in this way. 2.	Look up event organisers that hire young students for event managing posts. You may have to work rigorously for the time period of the event but the pay is usually very handsome. 3.	Take up internships. Look up internships through apps or search for them on the internet. They usually last for a month to 6 months and you may also choose to work from home in some cases. 4.	Put up stalls in fest. Fest take places in various places from colleges to local housing societies. Figure out the cost it will take you to set up a stall and decide on what sort of stall you want to put up. It could be a food stall as well as a product selling shop. 5.	Help by doing community services. These include various tasks from babysitting, gardening, running errands to tutoring, conducting an art/music/dance class for the younger kids around your house. 6.	Do home chores. If all goes wrong, ask your parents for extra allowance in exchange of doing home chores. Most likely parents would agree to this as they would be happy to know that you are ready to learn to take on some responsibility around the house.

I'm a student. I'm 16 years old and I probably make more money in a month than all my classmates combined (they probably don't make much). What do I do? Well I'm a stock trader. I usually don't get time to screen stocks throughout the day because of my school. I usually swing trade and make around 4% a week. That's what I chose to do. I think that real money is in trading. It took me 2 years to learn all this. I cant tell you what to do but what I can tell you us what not to do.  Don't fall into online surveys bullsh¡t. You hardly make a dollar for a few hours of work. Is your time worth so less? So what can you do? I think you can acquire high income skills like trading or copywriting and make courses on that once you master them or be a freelancer. Otherwise you can start a youtube channel or a blog. But it will be years before you make 10 dollars. Its hard work and time consuming. The more you think about money, the less money you make.

I can't believe no one has mentioned tutoring. If you have the ability, tutoring is an awesome way to make money. Depending on your school, area, and a variety of other factors, you may be able to pull in some serious scratch. Think of it this way, let's say you go to a standard public school, in a nice neighborhood. You could probably charge $10-$15 per hour for your services. Professional tutors are expensive, and your primary goal should be to seriously undercut the competition in order to compensate for a lack of experience. If you go with $15 an hour, you could tutor for two hours a night, three nights a week, and pull in $90 per week for six hours of work. Meanwhile, your friend working at a fast food joint is making that much for 10-11 hours of work. It is the best money for your time, and you can make a lot more by optimizing for your area and situation. Best of luck in any future ventures.

I’d say try and land a gig job on Fiverr or other sites like that. You can say you’re just starting out and want to build up a reputation, so you’ll do free work for reviews to build up your legitimacy and skills (unless you have a portfolio of some sort that shows experience in the work you want to do already). I’d say that’s a good way to start building connections, and connections are good to have in freelancing. Freelancing has many avenues of work available, and you will be surprised the different ways you can earn money aside from a “traditional job”, i.e. standing at a cash register for hours to be paid minimum wage. Your time is valuable, I’ve read you should value your time at $50 an hour. That could be valued as productivity, amount of fun you are having, skill-building, etc. You are the director of your life and you have the power to affect the outcomes in your life. Take executive action and don’t settle for less. I’ve done work on crowd-sourcing website such as Amazon Mechanical Turk, Prolific, Testable Minds. There are others out there, but those three are the ones I’ve had the most experience with. I highly recommend the first two, while the third has occasional work it can be a nuisance to validate yourself with a webcam each time a study comes up. You could look into starting an e-commerce store, do affiliate marketing, learn SEO and optimization, learn to write quick e-books that provide value, just learn and grow through experiencing the unknown. You never know what you are capable of until you try. Get after your goals, get motivated, take some responsibility for how you want to live! Don’t settle for less unless you feel you have to, it’s not about the end-goal but the journey. Good luck on everything.

Just get a part-time job. It's good to have some experience too, for later. When you're going to college, it's nice to have a little money, and you're going to earn that money by doing a part-time job. Now, when you're 18y/o+, your minimum wage suddenly is a lot higher than now, which sounds like a reason to start looking for a job when you're 18, but it is also a reason for people not to hire you, and instead hire a 16y/o whom they have to pay less. Therefore it's good to have some experience before you turn 18. I worked in a supermarket for three years (different supermarkets though),first as a stockboy and later as a cashier, which were really nice jobs. You often get a relatively good wage and it's sure you can work a nice amoumt of hours every week, trough the whole year. Also, if you want a day off, it's often easy to arrange someone eho can work for you instead. Another popular option is working in a restaurant. In a restaurant you often work long shifts, many days in the week, but that is mainly during vacations. The conditions are more harsh, the pay is not always guaranteed to be good, due to not having that many employees it can be hard to arrange a day off, but all those things are compensated for by the fact that during vacations, as I said, you can work a lot. And if you're lucky, you may get high fees.

While in High School I made 600–800€/year working about 2 hours per week. 2 hours per week is literally nothing. I did it in my spare time just for fun and I ended up saving almost all of it. Want to know what I did? Tutoring. A family friend needed someone to tutor his son as he struggled in Maths and Geometry. I went to his house 2 hours per week, earning 10€/hour (I would say it’s average price in Italy, especially for a high school teenager). I’ve been tutoring him for 3 years now and I love it. I’m attending University now and I’m tutoring also another kid, so I would say I work 3 hours per week, earning ~900€/year. I recommend this to everyone who is really good at a subject as you could earn good money working in your spare time. I’m tutoring just two kids but if you tutored more kids you could earn way more than what I earn, working just few hours per week. I know people who do this for a living: they have a Degree and therefore could possibly earn 20–30€/hour, maybe more, and also tutor a lot of kids earning enough to live comfortably.

When I was a teenager I did a lot of yard work. It was a pretty sweet gig. I saved up over $5,000.  But what I didn't know about back then was the power of investing and compound interest.  It is a powerful force. And it's more powerful the younger you take advantage of it.  I would recommend that you learn about investing. Read The Intelligent Investor. It's Warren Buffett's favorite investing book.  If you invest properly, that $5,000 would grow at 12% to 15% per year.  What you should try to do right now is to put your savings into a ROTH IRA. You can contribute a maximum of $5,500 per year into it. The great thing is, if you wait to withdraw your earnings until (I think it's) age 65, you don't have to pay taxes on any of your earnings. This is huge.  So let's say you save $10,000 as a teen. You invest this. You earn $1,200 your first year.  If you invest that $10,000 at a 12% return for 55 years... you will have over $5,000,000 in the bank.  thanks for reading, Eric Earle Director of Youth Development www.mentorportland.com

Realistically, a teen who hasn’t even found his passion yet is going to have a difficult time netting even thousands of dollars on their own. I’d (based on my set of skills) go into software development. I was into it as a teen and still am now, You could start working on some indie projects, charging a small fee for the purchase of a closed-source copy of your program. From there, if you have enough money, enlist/hire the help of some volunteers and work on a slightly larger project and charge a little more money. Remember to focus on quality above all else, otherwise, people won’t be very interested. Remember to pay off your employees regularly or at least when you can and have something remotely resembling a schedule. Alternatively, you could go open-source, or go on a site like get some crowd funding (just remember to make your product live up to the expectations set and perceived by people viewing your kickstarter campaign, otherwise you won’t look god in their eyes as a developer/producer).

Use your spare time to do building / gardening / car washing / cleaning etc and learn in a low risk environment how to run a business. I learnt the foundations of my later career by doing this. I eventually built a big business which I sold and retired young (see details in my other posts). I attribute a big part of my success to my experience running a small business when I was younger. I only wish that getting customers today was as easy as it was then. You didnt need a business plan or investors, just a big smile and a willingness to work hard. You could have 10 customers by the end of the day, just in your neighborhood! Start doing it today. The experience you gain is invaluable and will be a huge advantage when you start out on your own later in life.

I'm very scared at your statment "doing whatever to earn it".   What if someone offered you a job selling drugs? Its quick, easy, takes no skills and you will make money.  However,  I would highly recommend AGAINST it. You need to first have good intentions. What do you plan to do with the money?  Do you plan to save it for future education?  Do you plan to spend it on weed?  Do you plan to buy a hover board? First think of why you need the money.  That's your first step.   Now. . . do you think that "doing whatever" is worth what you need the money for? You didn't mention any skills you have.  Can you tutor on the side?  Can you build websites?  Can you help people run errands?    Make a list of things you can do.   Maybe that's a good question on quora after you have taken inventory of what you have to offer people in exchange for money.

If you’re interested in a medical career or want to look good for your college applications, I would reccomend you get your CNA (Certified Nurse Assistant). I’m planning on taking it this summer so I can see what a hospital environment is like and mainly just to get out of the house. I believe the minimum age in Texas is 16, and once you get it you can start working for about 12ish dollars an hour as compared to the minimum wage (7.25- all based in Texas). If you have a busy highschool life some places will let you work on the weekends, breaks, or summers. Not only does it pay well, but you get to experience a different environment that allows you to network and build relationships that could benefit you later on. Plus it’ll look great on college applications… >:)… Also, classes are really not that long. It usually takes 4–12 weeks including a minimum of 75 hours of instructions and clinical training. If you don’t want to be stuck at McDonald’s flipping patties or folding clothes at Justice, working as a CNS is a good job to have in highschool :).

Little odd jobs are great for money-making. Start with your family then branch out. Maybe your Mom has a pile of tangled jewelry she’d like untangled — ask if you can do it for a couple of bucks. (If she says no, I’d go ahead and do it anyway.) Ask your parents to tell their friends you’re looking to make money and see if anyone needs help cleaning a shed or watering plants, feeding fish, etc. However. The key is to not charge too much! $50 a day to walk a dog? Never! Try negotiating the price. $10–15 dollars is better, depending on how big the dog is and how long you need to walk him. $100 to clean out a shed might be reasonable depending on how much cleaning it needs. It starts out slow, but you get money for doing things that are going to be done anyway. Might as well be you who gets the money, right?

Like Saqib recommended in the article that he linked to, two great ways are blogging and Gaming on YouTube (Twitch as well). There are lots of ways to make money online. For example, if you're good at writing you could write blog posts and probably make bank if your articles are good. However, in a "teach a man to fish" fashion, I will move on to the more meta part of this question. There are basically two different ways to make money; to leverage a skill you have and work, or to start a business. You can use your skill to start your business. For example, with the article writing, you could potentially start as a one man article writing team. With enough capital, you could start outsourcing the articles and merely coordinating projects between other freelancers. This is a process known as bootstrapping. Whatever it is you decide you want to do, make sure you research your market. Research it a lot. Read about it whenever you possibly can, and don't ever stop trying to learn new things about it. That's the only way to get better, and in the process, make more money. Best of luck!

I'm able to use the shop during off hours, so I do a side project or two a month. I also teach primitive wilderness skills a few weekend days a month. You might have already heard hundred of thousands of methods and techniques to make money online but there are few things that you should ask yourself: 1: Investment: This is not necessarily money, even time is an investment. So how much time are you willing to spend or can you spend for this purpose is the first question that needs answer. 2: Strengths: What are your strengths? What are you really good at? You can make people pay you only if you give them value in terms of quality, professionalism and support. Find your answer to this question and read the next. 3: Weakness: If you have identified your strengths, then you should definitely know your weakness too. It could be even ‘fear of talking to a stranger.‘ Whatever it is, be honest and tell yourself this is your weakness. Only if you identify your weakness, you will be able to create a strategy to put your strengths to good use by circumventing your weakness. 4: Platform: This could be physical or digital. You can market yourself and try finding works by visiting local meetups, business community etc and this falls under the physical category. You can also do this effectively online. There are various platforms available these days. For example: Imagine that one of the strengths you have is that you are good at talking to people and you enjoy doing that. There is this language marketplace called Lughaa that helps you find language learners who are willing to pay you for a 15 minutes to 1 hour talking session so that they could practice talking with a native speaker. It’s free to register as a seller, so no investment there in terms of money. 5: Be creative: Competition is tough so in order to get good visibility, you need to be innovative and creative. All the best!

Cutting grass is pretty easy and can be lucrative. The pros charge ridiculous amounts so you can undercut them. Most people have lawnmowers so often times you can just use theirs. I used to have 3 lawns to cut every Saturday, charging $10–20 a piece. Tax free too. Target people that can't physically do it or don't have the time - the elderly and those with young kids. They feel like they're getting a deal and you get cash! Once you have a reputation for doing a good job, news will spread and it will be easy to pick up more work. Other jobs to try - shoveling snow, raking leaves, power washing, dog walking, and painting.

Mowing lawns was the best gig back in the day for teenagers. I made five times what my friends in retail or fast food were making, and set my own schedule. I hated getting up early in the morning, but in the South it was pretty miserable by noon so you needed to get most of your yards cut early. Step 1. You know ice cream, right? Step 2. Talk to your boss and ask if he would be willing to promote/give you a raise or small profit sharing if you can get all of your friends into his shop. Step 3. Don't worry if he says no, you are 15 years old responsibly working-do you have any savings? If so I would consider buying a used ice cream cart and getting a vendors licens-consumption license for your town. Step 4. Based on savings either ask or don't for your parents to invest in you-ask them before you start the whole thing. Step 5. If they say yes and give you enough for one day's inventory find a fair in town-whether in the summer or sooner. Step 6. Sell for a low price and tell your friends about it. Underprice the competition, they may be able to order in bulk but you don't need to pay yourself yet. Step 7. Do this at many fairs and maybe even find a small spot where you can sell regularly in town. Step 8. If everything goes well parents will be paid back, you will make money, and you will have a completely legitimate business venture. Depending on your state pest control can be very easy and profitable. I started my first pest control business at 17. I had to pass a test at the Utah division of agriculture (pretty easy, about $75), get a business license (local and federal, about $75), buy a back pack sprayer ($100), and a hand sprayer for inside ($8), then I bought a gallon of bifenthrin from univar ($30). So for about $300 you can get everything you need to start spraying for pest control. You typically dilute the chemicals 1 oz to 1 gal and use about 1 gal to spray the outside and inside of a small home or apartment. It takes 10-15 min and you can typically charge 50-75$ a home and easily beat what other companies are charging. Pm me if you have more questions. Also I still do this (I’m currently an engineering project manager, and do this on the weekends)

Start a Drop Shipping Business What is DropShipping? Dropshipping is a retail fulfillment method where a store doesn't keep the products it sells in stock. Instead, when a store sells a product, it purchases the item from a third party and has it shipped directly to the customer. As a result, the merchant never sees or handles the product. How much money I need? robably the biggest advantage to dropshipping is that it's possible to launch an ecommerce store without having to invest thousands of dollars in inventory up front. Traditionally, retailers have had to tie up huge amounts of capital purchasing inventory. How can I start? Reliable, easy, yields a lot of money pick 2. There are two ways to make money, either you provide a device or good someone wants, or you invest. Potentially high yield investments, like investing in a startup or gambling are very risky. The potential yield is high, but the expected yield is very low (often negative), because most of the time your money goes up in smoke. Goods or services that are easy to provide aren't valuable. Working at McDonald's pays very little because anyone can work at McDonald's. Professional football players make a lot of money because very few people can play football at a professional level. Generally a good or service is hard to provide either because it requires a lot of effort or training, or because it requires exceptional talent, or both. It's all supply and demand. The truth is there's no free lunch and no easy way to make money. Otherwise, everyone would already be doing it.Either you work hard or you get lucky or, most often, both.

Hey, There are many ways in which you can start making money as a teenager. You can do internships. You can take some kind of classes and tuitions. I will tell you what I did. When I was a student, I used to take tuitions and save money every month. I thought about investing my money. So, I researched and started saving money every month and decided to invest my money with Systematic Investment Plan (SIP). With SIP, you can invest a fixed amount in mutual funds step-by-step monthly or quarterly over a period of time, thereby averaging out your cost of investing and benefiting from the power of compounding. SIP is an investment vehicle offered by mutual funds to investors, allowing them to invest small amounts periodically instead of lump sums. The frequency of investment is usually weekly, monthly or quarterly. You can start with as low as Rs. 500 per month in SIP. This is an ideal option for starting investments initially. This kind of investment provides you the option to invest small amounts too. So saving money monthly and then investing it in SIP is very much possible. I did all my investments via Sharekhan. You will get guidance from an expert to start with your investment. SIP is best option for a student. You can get best returns after the maturity date. Such investments will help you in putting a habit of saving money. You will always save out a portion of your earnings and invest them. This is how you can start earning and investing as a Teenager. I am sure you will be happy about the decisions you made today for a better tomorrow. :)

Define “teenager”. Does “teenager” mean: “13 and unemployable except on a family farm, due to labor regulations”, OR“19 and a legal adult for almost 2 years, about to run 20, with a 2 year college degree”There is essentially no job market in the U.S. for anyone under the age of 18; that’s the age of majority, at which you are considered legally an adult. There are a number of reasons for this, but the increased child labor regulation is the main one. When my sister was 14, in 1978, she worked a food counter at a ski lodge, which they felt was perfectly fine for a 14 year old. The primary driver for the increased labor regulation is claimed to be on behalf of the children — but it’s not. It’s because all the “starter jobs” are being filled by blue collar workers who were formerly employed in manufacturing jobs which have been subsequently off shored. It prevent 14–17 year olds from competing with these workers for employment. So unless you meant “18 or 19” when you said “teenager”, you have a very limited set of options, you also have a very limited set of hours, and it’s worse during the school year.

As a teenager with a relatively steady financial state: there's no get-rich-quick scheme. Unless you resort to illicit activity, which I don't encourage. However, you can get a pretty good start in life by A) finding a part-time job B) being smart with your finances and C) investing some of your money. While a part time job won't afford you a ton of recreational spending money, saving your money right will set you up for a good start to your adulthood.

I had my own "Grit" paper route. I went out and got my own customers and went from door to door. My brother wanted my 10 speed in the middle of winter. He said, "I'll give you these skis for your 10 speed." I said, "OK", stupid but I loved my brother. He quickly traded it for a motor bike. To this day, he has 2 very nice motor bikes and I have none. I asked if he had crash bars on each side of his motor bikes. He said, "No". I said, "I've met 2 paraplegics so far who were forced into the guard rail and lost their legs and were paralyzed." To this day, I always remind people who are out riding to get crash bars to protect their legs.

The easiest way to make money as a teenager with no work experience is in one of the service industries, where they take you in knowing you have no experience, train you in some job they believe you can do, and then retain you if you perform as expected. It can be risky to invest in individual stocks. However, if you do, it is best that you read investment books/articles and research the companies. If the company invests in research and development, then they are likely to have good future growth. It is also important for a company to have excellent cash flow, low debt, and good inventory turnover. Also, you want to be cautious of buying companies who have to over rely on buying other businesses in order to grow. Are they buying good companies that will help increase their profits? Other important things to consider are the business’ moat, their revenue growth, and the number of stocks you include in your portfolio. Invest in different industries. I suggest accessing the websites: Types of Narrow Moats What is the ideal number of stocks to have in a portfolio? | Investopedia. I also recommend refraining from borrowing money especially when you are a beginning investor. When the market is doing well, it is tempting borrow. However, you could end up buying the stock at near the high price. Instead you should be greedy when most people are scared to invest and fearful when they are greedy. I suggest investing money you won’t need in 10 years because sometimes, a market downturn lasts a long time. I recommend investing your money in small chunks or buying index mutual funds. I hope this information helps!
